entries.title: Abandonment
definitions: Any true cessation. An emptiness of a mind that has completely abandoned a delusion or other fault.

entries.title: Abhidharma
definitions: Sanskrit word for `Phenomenologyâ€™. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Absorption
definitions: A virtuous single-pointed mind of the form or formless realm. They are of two types: close preparations, which are uninterrupted paths, and actual absorptions, which are released paths. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Absorption of cessation
definitions: An uncontaminated wisdom focused single-pointedly on emptiness in dependence upon the actual absorption of peak of samsara. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Absorption without discrimination
definitions: A concentration of the fourth form realm that observes nothingness and that is attained by stopping gross feelings and gross discriminations. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Action close retreat
definitions: See {{Close retreat}}.

entries.title: Action mudra
definitions: A Highest Yoga Tantra consort who assists in developing great bliss. See {{Clear Light of Bliss}} and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Action Tantra
definitions: See {{Four classes of Tantra}}.

entries.title: Affirming negative
definitions: See {{Negative phenomenon}}.

entries.title: Aggregate
definitions: In general, all functioning things are aggregates because they are an aggregation of their parts. In particular, a person of the desire realm or form realm has five aggregates: the aggregates of form, feeling, discrimination, compositional factors, and consciousness. A being of the formless realm lacks the aggregate of form but has the other four. A personâ€™s form aggregate is his or her body. The remaining four aggregates are aspects of his mind. entries.title: Aggression
definitions: A deluded mental factor that is an increase of the root delusion anger that wishes to hurt or harm others physically or verbally. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Akanishta
definitions: A Pure Land where Bodhisattvas attain enlightenment. See {{Clear Light of Bliss}}.

entries.title: Akshobya
definitions: The manifestation of the aggregate of consciousness of all Buddhas. He has a blue-coloured body.

entries.title: Alertness
definitions: A mental factor which is a type of wisdom that examines our activity of body, speech, and mind and knows whether or not faults are developing. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: All Good One
definitions: An English name for Samantabhadra, a Bodhisattva renowned for his extensive offerings. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}}. â€œ

entries.title: Amitabha
definitions: The manifestation of the aggregate of discrimination of all Buddhas. He has a red-coloured body.

entries.title: Amitayus
definitions: A Buddha who increases our lifespan, merit, and wisdom. He is the Enjoyment Body aspect of Buddha Amitabha.

entries.title: Amoghasiddhi
definitions: The manifestation of the aggregate of compositional factors of all Buddhas. He has a green-coloured body.

entries.title: Analysis
definitions: A mental factor that examines an object to gain an understanding of its subtle nature. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Analytical meditation
definitions: The mental process of investigating a virtuous object â€“ analyzing its nature, function, characteristics, and other aspects. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{The New Meditation Handbook}}.

entries.title: Anger
definitions: A deluded mental factor that observes its contaminated object, exaggerates its bad qualities, considers it to be undesirable, and wishes to harm it. See {{Understanding the Mind}} and {{How to Solve Our Human Problems}}.

links.title: How to Solve Our Human Problems

entries.title: Appearing object
definitions: In general, an object that appears to a mind. In the context of generation stage meditation, the appearing object is the mandala and Deities. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Arhat
definitions: Sanskrit term for {{Foe Destroyer}}. A practitioner who has abandoned all delusions and their seeds by training on the spiritual paths, and who will never again be reborn in samsara. In this context, the term `Foeâ€™ refers to the delusions.

entries.title: Arya

entries.title: Asanga
definitions: A great Indian Buddhist Yogi and scholar of the fifth century, author of Compendium of Abhidharma. See {{Living Meaningfully, Dying Joyfully}}.

entries.title: Aspiration
definitions: A mental factor that focuses on a desired object and takes an interest in it. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Aspiring bodhichitta
definitions: A mind that aspires to attain enlightenment for the benefit of all living beings but that does not yet engage in the actual practices of the Bodhisattvaâ€™s training. It is like someone intending to go somewhere but not yet setting out on the journey.

entries.title: Atisha (AD 982-1054)
definitions: A famous Indian Buddhist scholar and meditation master. He was Abbot of the great Buddhist monastery of Vikramashila at a time when Mahayana Buddhism was flourishing in India. He was later invited to Tibet and his arrival there led to the re-establishment of Buddhism in Tibet. He is the author of the first text on the stages of the path, Lamp for the Path. His tradition later became known as the `Kadampa Traditionâ€™. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Attachment
definitions: A deluded mental factor that observes a contaminated object, regards it as a cause of happiness, and wishes for it. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Attainment

Supreme attainments are the special realizations of a Buddha. See {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Attention
definitions: A mental factor that functions to focus the mind on a particular attribute of an object. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Avalokiteshvara
definitions: The embodiment of the compassion of all the Buddhas. Sometimes he appears with one face and four arms, and sometimes with eleven faces and a thousand arms. At the time of Buddha Shakyamuni, he manifested as a Bodhisattva disciple. Called â€˜Chenrezigâ€™ in Tibetan. See {{Living Meaningfully, Dying Joyfully}}.

entries.title: Awakened One

The â€˜sleep of ignoranceâ€™ is the sleep of self-grasping in which living beings always remain and from which they have never awakened.

entries.title: Awareness
definitions: All minds are included within the five sense awarenesses and mental awareness. There are five types of sense awareness: eye awareness, ear awareness, nose awareness, tongue awareness, and body awareness. There are two types of mental awareness: conceptual mental awareness and non-conceptual mental awareness. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Bardo
definitions: See {{Intermediate state}}.

entries.title: Basis of emptiness
definitions: Any phenomenon with respect to which inherent existence is negated in realizing its emptiness. Since all phenomena, including emptiness itself, are empty of inherent existence, all phenomena are bases of emptiness. In the Perfection of Wisdom Sutra in One Hundred Thousand Lines, Buddha explains that all phenomena are included within one hundred and eight categories, from form to omniscient mind, all of which are bases of emptiness. See {{Heart of Wisdom}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Basis of imputation
definitions: All phenomena are imputed upon their parts; therefore, any of the individual parts, or the entire collection of the parts, of any phenomenon is its basis of imputation. A phenomenon is imputed by mind in dependence upon its basis of imputation appearing to that mind. See {{Heart of Wisdom}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Beginningless time
definitions: According to the Buddhist world view, there is no beginning to mind and so no beginning to time. Therefore, all sentient beings have taken countless previous rebirths.

entries.title: Behar
definitions: A type of malevolent spirit. See {{Heart Jewel}}.

entries.title: Benzarahi
definitions: A female Buddha who is the manifestation of the fire element of all Buddhas. She is the consort of Buddha Amitabha.

entries.title: Bhaga
definitions: Sanskrit word for the female sex organ.

entries.title: Blessing
definitions: â€˜Jin gyi lab paâ€™ in Tibetan. The transformation of our mind from a negative state to a positive state, from an unhappy state to a happy state, or from a state of weakness to a state of strength, through the inspiration of holy beings such as our Spiritual Guide, Buddhas, and Bodhisattvas.

See also {{Aspiring bodhichitta}} and {{Engaging bodhichitta}}. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Meaningful to Behold}}.

entries.title: Bodhisattva
definitions: A person who has generated spontaneous bodhichitta but who has not yet become a Buddha. From the moment a practitioner generates a non-artificial, or spontaneous, bodhichitta, he or she becomes a Bodhisattva and enters the first Mahayana path, the path of accumulation. An ordinary Bodhisattva is one who has not realized emptiness directly, and a Superior Bodhisattva is one who has attained a direct realization of emptiness. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Meaningful to Behold}}.

entries.title: Bodhisattva vow
definitions: See {{Vow}}.

entries.title: Body mandala
definitions: The transformation into a Deity of any part of the body of a self-generated or in-front-generated Deity. See {{Essence of Vajrayana}}, {{Guide to Dakini Land}}, and {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Brahma
definitions: A worldly god, who resides in the first form realm. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Buddhadharma
definitions: See {{Dharma}}.

entries.title: Buddha family
definitions: There are five main Buddha families: the families of Vairochana, Ratnasambhava, Amitabha, Amoghasiddhi, and Akshobya. entries.title: Buddhahood
definitions: Synonymous with full enlightenment. See {{Enlightenment}}.

entries.title: Buddha Land
definitions: The pure environment of a Buddha.

entries.title: Buddha lineage
definitions: See {{Buddha seed}}.

entries.title: Buddha nature
definitions: See {{Buddha seed}}.

entries.title: Buddhaâ€™s bodies

See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}, {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}, and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Buddha Jewel
definitions: See {{Three Jewels}}.

entries.title: Buddha seed
definitions: The root mind of a sentient being, and its ultimate nature. Buddha seed, Buddha nature, and Buddha lineage are synonyms. All sentient beings have Buddha seed and therefore the potential to attain Buddhahood. See {{Mahamudra Tantra}}.

entries.title: Buddha Shakyamuni
definitions: The Buddha who is the founder of the Buddhist religion. See {{Introduction to Buddhism}}. Buddha Shakyamuni is the fourth of one thousand founding Buddhas who are to appear in this world during this Fortunate Aeon. The first three were Krakuchchanda, Kanakamuni, and Kashyapa. The fifth Buddha will be Maitreya. See {{Introduction to Buddhism}}.

entries.title: Buddhas
definitions: , one thousand According to common appearance, one thousand Buddhas will appear in this world. Buddha Shakyamuni was the fourth and Buddha Maitreya will be the fifth.

entries.title: Buddhist
definitions: Anyone who from the depths of his or her heart goes for refuge to the Three Jewels â€“ Buddha Jewel, Dharma Jewel, and Sangha Jewel. See {{Introduction to Buddhism}}.

entries.title: Central channel
definitions: The principal channel at the very centre of the body, along which the channel wheels, or chakras, are located. See {{Clear Light of Bliss}}.

entries.title: Chakra
definitions: See {{Channel wheel}}.

entries.title: Chakravatin king
definitions: An extremely fortunate being who has accumulated a vast amount of merit and as a result has taken rebirth as a king with dominion over all four continents as described in Buddhist cosmology, or, at the very least, over one of the four continents. At present there are no Chakravatin kings in our world, and there is no one who has complete dominion over our continent, Jambudipa. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Chandrakirti

entries.title: Channels

entries.title: Chenrezig

entries.title: Clear light
definitions: A manifest very subtle mind that perceives an appearance like clear, empty space. See {{Clear Light of Bliss}}, {{Mahamudra Tantra}}, and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Close placement of mindfulness
definitions: A path of concentration that depends upon mindfulness and wisdom. There are four types: close placement of mindfulness of body, close placement of mindfulness of feelings, close placement of mindfulness of mind, and close placement of mindfulness of phenomena. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Close retreat
definitions: A retreat during which we strive to draw close to a particular Deity. This can be understood in two ways: drawing close in the sense of developing a special relationship with a friend, and drawing close in the sense of becoming more and more like the Deity. An action close retreat is a close retreat in which we collect a certain number of mantras and conclude with a fire puja. See {{Heart Jewel}}, {{Guide to Dakini Land}}, {{Essence of Vajrayana}}, and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Collection of merit
definitions: A virtuous action motivated by bodhichitta that is a main cause of attaining the Form Body of a Buddha. Examples are: making offerings and prostrations to holy beings with bodhichitta motivation, and the practice of the perfections of giving, moral discipline, and patience.

entries.title: Collection of wisdom
definitions: A virtuous mental action motivated by bodhichitta that is a main cause of attaining the Truth Body of a Buddha. Examples are: listening to, contemplating, and meditating on emptiness with bodhichitta motivation.

entries.title: Collective karma
definitions: The karma we create when we act in association with others. Those who create karma together also experience its effects together.

entries.title: Commitment being
definitions: A visualized Buddha or ourself visualized as a Buddha. entries.title: Commitments

entries.title: Common attainments

entries.title: Compassion

entries.title: Completion stage

entries.title: Compositional equanimity
definitions: A mental factor that functions to keep the primary mind free from mental sinking and mental excitement. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Compositional factors
definitions: The aggregate of compositional factors comprises all mental factors except feeling and discrimination, as well as non-associated compounded phenomena. See {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: Concealment

entries.title: Consciousness
definitions: The six consciousnesses, or primary minds, are the eye consciousness, ear consciousness, nose consciousness, tongue consciousness, body consciousness, and mental consciousness. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Consideration for others
definitions: A mental factor that functions to avoid inappropriate actions for reasons that concern others. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Contact
definitions: A mental factor that functions to perceive its object as pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Contaminated aggregate
definitions: Any of the aggregates of form, feeling, discrimination, compositional factors, and consciousness of a samsaric being. See also {{Aggregate}}. See {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: Contaminated phenomenon

definitions: Any phenomenon other than emptiness. Conventional truths are true with respect to the minds of ordinary beings, but in reality they are false. See {{Heart of Wisdom}}, {{Meaningful to Behold}}, and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Correct belief
definitions: A non-valid cognizer that realizes its conceived object. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Creative yoga

entries.title: Cyclic existence

See {{Heart Jewel}}.

entries.title: Damaru
definitions: A small hand-drum used in Tantric rituals. Playing the damaru symbolizes the gathering of the outer Dakinis into our body, and the manifestation of the inner Dakini (the mind of clear light) within our mind through the blazing of inner fire. It is also used as a music offering to the Buddhas.

entries.title: Death
definitions: The permanent separation of body and mind. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Clear Light of Bliss}}.

entries.title: Dedication

definitions: A non-valid cognizer that realizes its conceived object. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Creative yoga
definitions: See {{Generation stage}}.

entries.title: Cyclic existence
definitions: See {{Samsara}}.

entries.title: Dakini Land
definitions: The Pure Land of Heruka and Vajrayogini. In Sanskrit it is called `Keajraâ€™ and in Tibetan `Dagpa KhachÃ¶â€™. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Dalai Lama
definitions: This title, meaning `Ocean Lamaâ€™, was given by the Mongolian ruler Altan Khan to Sonam Gyatso (AD 1543-1588). Although he was the first to be so called, he became known as the third Dalai Lama, his two previous incarnations acquiring posthumously the titles of first and second Dalai Lama. See {{Heart Jewel}}.

entries.title: Damaru
definitions: A small hand-drum used in Tantric rituals. Playing the damaru symbolizes the gathering of the outer Dakinis into our body, and the manifestation of the inner Dakini (the mind of clear light) within our mind through the blazing of inner fire. It is also used as a music offering to the Buddhas.

entries.title: Death
definitions: The permanent separation of body and mind. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Clear Light of Bliss}}.

entries.title: Dedication
definitions: Dedication is by nature a virtuous mental factor; it is the virtuous intention that functions both to prevent accumulated virtue from degenerating and to cause its increase. If we dedicate our virtuous actions of body, speech, and mind to our own and othersâ€™ enlightenment, we prevent the merit of these actions from being destroyed or depleted and ensure that we experience their good results. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Degenerate times
definitions: A period when spiritual activity degenerates.

entries.title: Deity
definitions: â€˜Yidamâ€™ in Sanskrit. A Tantric enlightened being.

entries.title: Deity body Divine body
definitions: . When a practitioner attains an illusory body, he or she attains an actual divine body, or Deity body, but not a Deityâ€™s body. A Deityâ€™s body is necessarily a body of a Tantric enlightened being. See also {{Divine body}}. See {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Dominant condition
definitions: That which principally assists the development of a sense or mental awareness. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Dorje ShugdÃ¤n
definitions: A Dharma Protector who is an emanation of the Wisdom Buddha Manjushri. His main functions are to avert the inner and outer obstacles that prevent practitioners from gaining spiritual realizations, and to arrange all the necessary conditions for their spiritual development. See {{Heart Jewel}}.

entries.title: Doubt
definitions: A mental factor that wavers with respect to its object. See also {{Deluded doubt}}. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: DromtÃ¶npa (AD 1004-1064)
definitions: Atishaâ€™s foremost disciple. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Drops
definitions: There are two types of drop in the body: white drops and red drops. These are the pure essence of sperm and blood. When the drops melt and flow through the inner channels, they give rise to an experience of bliss. See {{Clear Light of Bliss}} and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Dualistic appearance
definitions: The appearance to mind of an object together with the inherent existence of that object. See {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: Dullness
definitions: A deluded mental factor that functions to make both the body and mind heavy and inflexible. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Effort
definitions: A mental factor that makes its primary mind delight in virtue. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Eight freedoms and ten endowments
definitions: Eight freedoms from impediment to spiritual practice and ten special conditions for spiritual practice that characterize a precious human life. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Eight Great Sons
definitions: The eight principal Mahayana disciples of Buddha Shakyamuni: Avalokiteshvara, Manjushri, Vajrapani, Maitreya, Samantabhadra, Ksitigarbha, Sarvanivaranaviskambini, and Akashagarbha. At the time of Buddha, they appeared in the aspect of Bodhisattvas, demonstrating the correct manner of practising the Mahayana paths and helping to spread Buddhaâ€™s teachings extensively for the benefit of others.

entries.title: Eight signs of dissolution
definitions: Internal signs that the inner winds are dissolving within the central channel. For a detailed description of each sign, see {{Clear Light of Bliss}}.

entries.title: Eight unfree states
definitions: Eight states into which we can be reborn. They are: rebirth as a hell being, rebirth as a hungry ghost, rebirth as an animal, rebirth as an ordinary god, rebirth in a country where there is no religion, rebirth where there is no Buddhadharma, rebirth with mental or physical disability, and rebirth as one who holds wrong views denying Dharma. They are called `unfreeâ€™ states because they allow no freedom for spiritual practice. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Eight Verses of Training the Mind
definitions: Lojong Tsig Gyema in Tibetan. Composed by Bodhisattva Langri Tangpa in the eleventh century, this text reveals the essence of the Mahayana Buddhist path to enlightenment. For a full commentary, see {{Eight Steps to Happiness}}.

entries.title: Eight worldly concerns
definitions: The objects of the eight worldly concerns are happiness and suffering, wealth and poverty, praise and criticism, and good reputation and bad reputation. These are called `worldly concernsâ€™ because worldly people are constantly concerned with them, wanting some and trying to avoid others. See {{Universal Compassion}} and {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Element
definitions: (Tib. kham) The nature of any phenomenon. All phenomena hold their own natures, which are all included within the eighteen elements. See also {{elements}}, four. See {{Heart of Wisdom}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Elements
definitions: (Tib. jung wa) Earth, water, fire, wind, and space. All matter can be said to be composed of a combination of these elements. There are five inner elements (those that are conjoined with the continuum of a person), and five outer elements (those that are not conjoined with the continuum of a person). These elements are not the same as the earth of a field, the water of a river, and so forth. Rather, the elements of earth, water, fire, wind, and space in broad terms are the properties of solidity, liquidity, heat, movement, and space respectively.

entries.title: Emanation
definitions: Animate or inanimate form manifested by Buddhas or high Bodhisattvas to benefit others.

entries.title: Emanation Body
definitions: â€˜Nirmanakayaâ€™ in Sanskrit. A gross Form Body of a Buddha that can be seen by ordinary beings. There are two types â€“ the Supreme Emanation Body and the ordinary Emanation Body. The first type can be seen only by those who have pure karma, and the second can be seen by anyone. In general, Buddhas manifest in many different forms and, although the aspect of some of these emanations is mundane, in essence all Buddhaâ€™s emanations are fully enlightened beings. See also {{Supreme Emanation Body}}. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}, {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}, and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Empowerment
definitions: A special potential power to attain any of the four Buddha bodies that is received by a Tantric practitioner from his or her Guru, or from other holy beings, by means of Tantric ritual. The gateway through which we enter Tantra is receiving a Tantric empowerment, which bestows upon us special blessings that heal our mental continuum and awaken our Buddha nature. When we receive a Tantric empowerment, we are sowing the special seeds of the four bodies of a Buddha upon our mental continuum. See {{Mahamudra Tantra}} and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Emptiness
definitions: Lack of inherent existence, the ultimate nature of phenomena. See {{Transform Your Life}}, {{Heart of Wisdom}}, and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Energy winds
definitions: See {{Inner winds}}.

entries.title: Engaging bodhichitta
definitions: A bodhichitta held by {{The Bodhisattva Vow}}. After we have taken The Bodhisattva Vow our aspiring bodhichitta transforms into engaging bodhichitta, which is a mind that actually engages in the practices that lead to enlightenment. See also {{Bodhichitta}}.

entries.title: Enjoyment Body
definitions: â€˜Sambhogakayaâ€™ in Sanskrit. A Buddhaâ€™s subtle Form Body that can be perceived only by Mahayana Superiors. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}, {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}, and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Enlightenment
definitions: Usually the full enlightenment of Buddhahood â€“ an omniscient wisdom whose nature is the permanent cessation of mistaken appearance and whose function is to bestow mental peace on all living beings. Generally, there are three levels of enlightenment: small enlightenment, or the enlightenment of a Hearer; middling enlightenment, or the enlightenment of a Solitary Realizer; and great enlightenment, or the enlightenment of a Buddha, also known as â€˜Buddhahoodâ€™. An enlightenment is a liberation and a true cessation. See {{Clear Light of Bliss}}, {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}, {{Ocean of Nectar}}, {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}, and {{Mahamudra Tantra}}.

entries.title: Ensa Whispered Lineage
definitions: Another name for the Uncommon Whispered Lineage of the Virtuous Tradition. See also {{Kadam Emanation Scripture}}.

entries.title: Equalizing self and others
definitions: See {{Lojong}}.

entries.title: Equanimity
definitions: A balanced mind free from strong attachment and aversion. There are three types of equanimity: equanimity of feeling, which is any neutral feeling; immeasurable equanimity, which is the wish for all beings equally to be free from attachment and hatred; and compositional equanimity, which is a mental factor that functions to keep the primary mind free from mental sinking and mental excitement. See {{Understanding the Mind}} and {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Essence of Good Fortune
definitions: A Sadhana consisting of prayers for the six preparatory practices. See also {{Preparatory practices}}. For a full commentary, see {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Essence of Wisdom Sutra
definitions: One of several Perfection of Wisdom Sutras that Buddha taught. Although much shorter than the other Perfection of Wisdom Sutras, it contains explicitly or implicitly their entire meaning. Also known as the Heart Sutra. For a full commentary, see {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: Exalted awareness
definitions: A spiritual realization that knows perfectly the nature of its principal object. Sometimes called `exalted wisdomâ€™. See {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Exalted wisdom
definitions: See {{Exalted awareness}}.

entries.title: Example clear light
definitions: A mind of clear light that realizes emptiness by means of a generic image. See {{Clear Light of Bliss}}.

entries.title: Exchanging self with others
definitions: See {{Lojong}}.

entries.title: Expressive sound
definitions: An object of hearing that makes its expressed object understood. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Extreme of attachment
definitions: Also known as the â€˜extreme of samsaraâ€™, this refers to being attached to the true existence of phenomena and thus remaining in Samsara due to delusion and karma.

entries.title: Extreme of fear
definitions: Also known as the â€˜extreme of solitary peaceâ€™, this refers to being afraid of the sufferings of Samsara and as a result seeking liberation for oneself alone.

entries.title: Extremes of existence and non-existence
definitions: Buddha explains the middle way by refuting the two extremes: the extreme of existence (that phenomena are inherently existent), and the extreme of non-existence (that phenomena do not exist at all). See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Extreme view
definitions: A deluded view that observes the I that is the conceived object of the view of the transitory collection and grasps it either as permanent or as completely ceasing at the time of death. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Faith
definitions: A mental factor that functions principally to eliminate non-faith. Faith is a naturally virtuous mind that functions mainly to oppose the perception of faults in its observed object. There are three types of faith: believing faith, admiring faith, and wishing faith. See {{Transform Your Life}}, {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}, and {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Father Tantra
definitions: A Tantra that principally reveals methods for attaining the illusory body.

entries.title: Feeling
definitions: A mental factor that functions to experience pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral objects. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Field for Accumulating Merit
definitions: Generally, the Three Jewels. Just as external seeds grow in a field of soil, so the virtuous internal seeds produced by virtuous actions grow in dependence upon Buddha Jewel, Dharma Jewel, and Sangha Jewel. Also known as `Field of Meritâ€™.

entries.title: Fire Deity
definitions: The Deity to whom we make the burning offering, for example in the practice of Heruka. A Fire Deity can be either mundane or supramundane. Mundane Fire Deities are not real mundane beings but appear in the aspect of mundane beings.

entries.title: Firm apprehension
definitions: A mental factor that makes its primary mind apprehend its object firmly. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Five Buddha families
definitions: See {{Buddha family}}.

entries.title: Five delusions
definitions: In the context of blessing the inner offering, the five delusions are: self-grasping, attachment, miserliness, jealousy, and confusion. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Five exalted wisdoms
definitions: Buddhaâ€™s omniscient wisdom has five parts: (1) the exalted mirror-like wisdom, which perceives all phenomena simultaneously as a mirror reflects objects; (2) the exalted wisdom of equality, which realizes that all phenomena are equal in emptiness; (3) the exalted wisdom of individual realization, which realizes all individual phenomena directly; (4) the exalted wisdom of accomplishing activities, whose function is to accomplish all the activities of a Buddha; and (5) the exalted wisdom of the Dharmadhatu, which realizes the Dharmadhatu, the ultimate nature of all phenomena.

entries.title: Five heinous actions
definitions: These are the five worst negative actions: killing oneâ€™s father, killing oneâ€™s mother, killing a Foe Destroyer, drawing the blood of a Buddha with harmful intention, and causing division within the Sangha or Dharma community. Also known as the `five actions of immediate retributionâ€™.

entries.title: Five omniscient wisdoms
definitions: See {{Five exalted wisdoms}}.

entries.title: Five stages of completion stage
definitions: In general, this refers to isolated speech, isolated mind, illusory body, clear light, and union. Sometimes it is used to refer to the five stages of blessing the self and so forth. See {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}, {{Clear Light of Bliss}}, {{Mahamudra Tantra}}, and {{Essence of Vajrayana}}.

entries.title: Foe Destroyer
definitions: â€˜Arhatâ€™ in Sanskrit. A practitioner who has abandoned all delusions and their seeds by training on the spiritual paths, and who will never again be reborn in samsara. In this context, the term `Foeâ€™ refers to the delusions. See also {{Hearer}}.

entries.title: Forgetfulness
definitions: A deluded mental factor that makes us forget a virtuous object. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Form
definitions: See {{Form aggregate}}, Form that is a phenomena source, and Visual form.

entries.title: Form aggregate
definitions: Includes all the objects of the five sense awarenessesâ€”all colors and shapes (visual form), sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile objects. A personâ€™s form aggregate is his or her body.

entries.title: Form Body
definitions: The Enjoyment Body and the Emanation Body of a Buddha. The first is his or her subtle Form Body and the second, of which each Buddha manifests a countless number, are gross Form Bodies that are visible to ordinary beings. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}, {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}, and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Form realm
definitions: The environment of the gods who possess form.

entries.title: Formless realm
definitions: The environment of the gods who do not possess form.

entries.title: Form that is a phenomena source
definitions: Form that appears exclusively to mental awareness, such as a dream mountain that appears to a dream eye awareness. See also {{Phenomena source}}. See {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Fortunate Aeon
definitions: The name given to this world age. It is so called because one thousand founding Buddhas will appear during this Aeon. Buddha Shakyamuni was the fourth and Buddha Maitreya will be the fifth. An Aeon in which no Buddhas appear is called a `Dark Aeonâ€™.

entries.title: Four classes of Tantra
definitions: Buddha taught four classes of Tantra: Action (Sanskrit Kriya) Tantra, Performance (Sanskrit. Charya) Tantra, Yoga Tantra, and Highest Yoga (Sanskrit. Anuttarayoga) Tantra. Each of the four classes of Tantra contains its own special techniques for transforming sensual bliss into the path to enlightenment. See also {{Tantra}}. See {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Four complete purities
definitions: A Tantric practice is one that possesses the four complete purities: (1) complete purity of place â€“ the environment is seen as the mandala of the Deity; (2) complete purity of body â€“ ordinary appearance of the body is prevented and the practitioner imagines that he or she possesses the body of a Deity; (3) complete purity of enjoyments â€“ sense enjoyments are transformed into offerings to the Deity; and (4) complete purity of deeds â€“ the practitioner regards all his or her actions as the actions of the Deity. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}} and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Four fearlessnesses
definitions: Special qualities of a Buddha. A fearlessness is an utterly firm, ultimate realization that is entirely free from fear in expounding Dharma. There are four types: (1) fearlessness in revealing the Dharma of definite emergence, (2) fearlessness in revealing the Dharma of overcoming obstructions, (3) fearlessness in revealing the Dharma of excellent abandonments, and (4) fearlessness in revealing the Dharma of excellent realizations. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Four immeasurables
definitions: Immeasurable equanimity, immeasurable love, immeasurable compassion, and immeasurable joy. So called because we practise them taking as our observed object all living beings whose number is immeasurable. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Four joys
definitions: Four stages of bliss that are generated in the generation and completion stages of Highest Yoga Tantra. See {{Clear Light of Bliss}}.

entries.title: Four Maras
definitions: See {{Mara/Demon}}.

entries.title: Four noble truths
definitions: True sufferings, true origins, true cessations, and true paths. They are called `nobleâ€™ truths because they are supreme objects of meditation. Through meditation on these four objects, we can realize ultimate truth directly and thus become a noble, or Superior, being. Sometimes referred to as the `four truths of Superiorsâ€™. According to the Madhyamika-Prasangika school, there are two types of four noble truths: gross and subtle. This is because there are two types of self-grasping of persons, gross self-grasping of persons â€“ grasping at a self-supporting, substantially existent person, and subtle self-grasping of persons â€“ grasping at an inherently existent person. See also {{Sixteen characteristics of the four noble truths}}. See {{How to Solve Our Human Problems}}, {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

How to Solve Our Human Problems

entries.title: Four opponent powers
definitions: Four powers that are essential for successful purification: the power of reliance, the power of regret, the power of the opponent force, and the power of promise. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}, {{The Bodhisattva Vow}}, and {{Meaningful to Behold}}.

entries.title: Four protections
definitions: Special qualities of a Buddha through which he or she is able to protect sentient beings from the four maras, or demons.

entries.title: Four ways of gathering disciples
definitions: The four ways of gathering disciples practised by Bodhisattvas are: (1) pleasing others by giving them material things or whatever they need; (2) teaching Dharma to lead others to liberation; (3) helping others in their Dharma practice by giving them encouragement; and (4) showing others a good example by always practising what we teach.

entries.title: Functioning thing
definitions: A phenomenon that is produced and disintegrates within a moment. Synonymous with impermanent phenomenon, thing, and product. See also {{Impermanent phenomenon}}.

entries.title: Ganden
definitions: `Tushitaâ€™ in Sanskrit, `Joyful Landâ€™ in English. The Pure Land of Buddha Maitreya. Both {{Je Tsongkhapa}} and {{Atisha}} went to this Pure Land after they passed away. Also the name of the monastery in Tibet founded by Je Tsongkhapa, and of the special doctrine revealed by Je Tsongkhapa. See {{Heart Jewel}}.

entries.title: Ganden Emanation Scripture
definitions: See {{Kadam Emanation Scripture}}.

entries.title: Ganden LhagyÃ¤ma
definitions: See {{Hundreds of Deities of the Joyful Land}}.

links.title: Hundreds of Deities of the Joyful Land

entries.title: GÃ¤ndhavajra
definitions: The emptiness of smell appearing in the form of an offering goddess. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Gelug
definitions: The tradition established by {{Je Tsongkhapa}}. The name `Gelugâ€™ means `Virtuous Traditionâ€™. A Gelugpa is a practitioner who follows this tradition. The Gelugpas are sometimes referred to as the â€˜new Kadampasâ€™. See {{Heart Jewel}}.

entries.title: Generation stage
definitions: A realization of a creative yoga prior to attaining the actual completion stage, which is attained through the practice of bringing the three bodies into the path, in which one mentally generates oneself as a Tantric Deity and oneâ€™s surroundings as the Deityâ€™s mandala. Meditation on generation stage is called a `creative yogaâ€™ because its object is created, or generated, by correct imagination. See {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}, {{Mahamudra Tantra}}, {{Guide to Dakini Land}}, and {{Essence of Vajrayana}}.

entries.title: Generic image
definitions: The appearing object of a conceptual mind. A generic image, or mental image, of an object is like a reflection of that object. Conceptual minds know their object through the appearance of a generic image of that object, not by seeing the object directly. The conceptual mind mistakes the generic image, or mental image, for the object itself. For example, if we think about our mother, an image of our mother appears to our conceptual mind, and it seems to that mind as if our mother herself is appearing. However, the object that principally appears to that mind is the generic image of our mother. This generic image appears to our mind through the mental exclusion of all objects that are not our mother. It is therefore the appearance of a non-non-mother. As such, like all generic images, it is a permanent phenomenon, whereas our mother herself is impermanent. See {{Heart of Wisdom}} and {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Geshe
definitions: A title given by Kadampa monasteries to accomplished Buddhist scholars. Contracted form of the Tibetan `ge wai she nyenâ€™, literally meaning `virtuous friendâ€™.

entries.title: Ghantapa
definitions: A great Indian Mahasiddha and a lineage Guru in the Highest Yoga Tantra practice of Vajrayogini. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Giving
definitions: A virtuous mental decision to give, or a bodily or verbal action of giving that is motivated by a virtuous state of mind. There are four types of giving: giving material things, giving Dharma, giving love, and giving fearlessness. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Meaningful to Behold}}.

entries.title: God
definitions: â€˜Devaâ€™ in Sanskrit. A being of the god realm, the highest of the six realms of samsara. There are many different types of god. Some are desire realm gods, while others are form or formless realm gods. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Goddesses of the doorways
definitions: The four Goddesses of the doorways are Kakase, literally â€˜crow-faced oneâ€™; Ulukase, â€˜owl-faced oneâ€™; ShÃ¶nase, â€˜dog-faced oneâ€™; and Shukarase, â€˜pig-faced oneâ€™. Although they have human-shaped heads and ears, their names reflect the appearances of their faces, which are like a crow, like an owl, and so on, rather as if they are wearing masks.

entries.title: Golden age
definitions: A time when sentient beings have abundant merit and when Dharma activities flourish. It is contrasted with degenerate times.

entries.title: Great compassion
definitions: A mind wishing to protect all sentient beings from suffering. Generally there are three types: compassion observing sentient beings, compassion observing phenomena, and compassion observing the unobservable. The second is a great compassion induced by and accompanied by a realization of impermanence, and the third is a great compassion induced by and accompanied by a realization of emptiness. The first is a great compassion that is not qualified in either of these ways. See {{Eight Steps to Happiness}}, {{Universal Compassion}}, and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Great liberation
definitions: Great enlightenment, or Buddhahood.

entries.title: Great nirvana
definitions: See {{Great liberation}}.

entries.title: Great seal
definitions: See {{Mahamudra}}.

entries.title: Great scope practitioner
definitions: A spiritual practitioner who emphasizes attaining enlightenment for the benefit of others. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Ground/Spiritual ground
definitions: A clear realization that acts as the foundation of many good qualities. A clear realization is a realization held by spontaneous renunciation or bodhichitta. The ten grounds are the realizations of Superior Bodhisattvas: Very Joyful, Stainless, Luminous, Radiant, Difficult to Overcome, Approaching, Gone Afar, Immovable, Good Intelligence, and Cloud of Dharma. See also {{Path/Spiritual path}} path. See {{Ocean of Nectar}} and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Guhyasamaja
definitions: A Highest Yoga Tantra Deity. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Guide to the Bodhisattvaâ€™s Way of Life
definitions: A classic Mahayana Buddhist text composed by the great Indian Buddhist Yogi and scholar Shantideva, which presents all the practices of a Bodhisattva from the initial generation of bodhichitta through to the completion of the practice of the six perfections. For a translation, see {{Guide to the Bodhisattvaâ€™s Way of Life}}. For a full commentary, see {{Meaningful to Behold}}.

links.title: Guide to the Bodhisattvaâ€™s Way of Life

entries.title: Guru
definitions: See {{Root Guru and Spiritual Guide}}.

entries.title: Guru yoga
definitions: A special way of relying upon our Spiritual Guide in order to receive his or her blessings. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}, {{Great Treasury of Merit}}, and {{Heart Jewel}}.

entries.title: Gyaltsabje (AD 1364-1432)
definitions: One of the principal disciples of Je Tsongkhapa. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Gyalwa EnsÃ¤pa (AD 1505-1566)
definitions: A great Yogi and Mahamudra lineage Guru who attained enlightenment in three years. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Happiness
definitions: There are two types of happiness: mundane and supramundane. Mundane happiness is the limited happiness that can be found within samsara, such as the happiness of human beings and gods. Supramundane happiness is the pure happiness of liberation and enlightenment.

entries.title: Harmfulness
definitions: A deluded mental factor that wishes other sentient beings to suffer. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Hashang
definitions: A Chinese monk of the twelfth century who propagated many wrong views in Tibet, including the view that the meaning of Buddhaâ€™s teachings on emptiness was that we should empty our mind of all conceptions and meditate on nothingness. He was publicly defeated in debate by Kamalashila and banished from Tibet. See {{Ocean of Nectar}} and {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Hearer
definitions: One of two types of Hinayana practitioner. Both Hearers and Solitary Conquerors are Hinayanists, but they differ in their motivation, behaviour, merit, and wisdom. In all these respects, Solitary Conquerors are superior to Hearers. Hearers are of eight types according to the level of delusions they have abandoned. (1) approachers to the accomplishment of a Stream Enterer, (2) abiders in the accomplishment of a Stream Enterer, (3) approachers to the accomplishment of a Once Returner, (4) abiders in the accomplishment of a Once Returner, (5) approachers to the accomplishment of a Never Returner, (6) abiders in the accomplishment of a Never Returner, (7) approachers to the accomplishment of a Foe Destroyer, and (8) abiders in the accomplishment of a Foe Destroyer. A Stream Enterer is on the path of seeing and will never again be reborn in the three lower realms; a Once Returner will return to the desire realm only once more; and a Never Returner will never again return to the desire realm. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Heart channel wheel
definitions: The channel wheel (Skt. chakra) at our heart. See {{Clear Light of Bliss}} and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Heart Sutra
definitions: One of several Perfection of Wisdom Sutras that Buddha taught. Although much shorter than the other Perfection of Wisdom Sutras, it contains explicitly or implicitly their entire meaning. Also known as the Essence of Wisdom Sutra. For a full commentary, see {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: Hell realm
definitions: The lowest of the six realms of samsara. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Heruka
definitions: A principal Deity of Mother Tantra, who is the embodiment of indivisible bliss and emptiness. He has a blue-coloured body, four faces, and twelve arms, and embraces his consort Vajravarahi. See {{Essence of Vajrayana}}.

entries.title: Hevajra
definitions: A principal Deity of Mother Tantra. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Hidden object
definitions: An object whose initial realization by a valid cognizer depends upon correct logical reasons. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Highest Yoga Tantra
definitions: The supreme quick path to enlightenment. The teachings on Highest Yoga Tantra are Buddhaâ€™s ultimate intention. See also {{Four classes of Tantra}}) and {{Tantra}}. See {{Mahamudra Tantra}} and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Hinayana
definitions: Sanskrit term for [object Object]. The Hinayana goal is to attain merely oneâ€™s own liberation from suffering by completely abandoning delusions. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Holding false views as supreme
definitions: A deluded view that holds a false view to be correct and superior to other views. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Holding wrong moral disciplines and conduct as supreme
definitions: A deluded view that holds any wrong moral discipline or conduct to be correct and considers it to be superior to other forms of moral discipline or conduct. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Holy being
definitions: A being who is worthy of devotion

entries.title: Humility
definitions: A virtuous mental factor whose main function is to reduce deluded pride.

entries.title: Hundreds of Deities of the Joyful Land
definitions: [object Object] in Tibetan. A special Guru yoga of Je Tsongkhapa in which Je Tsongkhapa and his two Sons are invited from the Joyful Land, or Tushita. See {{Heart Jewel}}.

entries.title: Hungry spirit
definitions: A being of the hungry spirit realm, the second lowest of the six realms of samsara. Also known as â€˜Hungry ghostâ€™. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Ignorance
definitions: A mental factor that is confused about the ultimate nature of phenomena. See also {{Self-grasping}}. See

entries.title: Illusory body
definitions: The subtle divine body that is principally developed from the indestructible wind. When a practitioner of Highest Yoga Tantra rises from the meditation of the isolated mind of ultimate example clear light, he or she attains a body that is not the same as his or her ordinary physical body. This new body is the illusory body. It has the same appearance as the body of the personal Deity of generation stage except that it is white in colour. It can be perceived only by those who have already attained an illusory body. See {{Clear Light of Bliss}} and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Impermanent phenomenon
definitions: Phenomena are either permanent or impermanent. `Impermanentâ€™ means `momentaryâ€™; thus an impermanent phenomenon is a phenomenon that is produced and disintegrates within a moment. Synonyms of impermanent phenomenon are `functioning thingâ€™, â€˜thingâ€™, and `productâ€™. There are two types of impermanence: gross and subtle. Gross impermanence is any impermanence that can be seen by an ordinary sense awareness â€“ for example the ageing and death of a sentient being. Subtle impermanence is the momentary disintegration of a functioning thing. See {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: Imprint
definitions: There are two types of imprint: imprints of actions and imprints of delusions. Every action we perform leaves an imprint on the mental consciousness, and these imprints are karmic potentialities to experience certain effects in the future. The imprints left by delusions remain even after the delusions themselves have been abandoned, rather as the smell of garlic lingers in a container after the garlic has been removed. Imprints of delusions are obstructions to omniscience, and are completely abandoned only by Buddhas.

entries.title: Imputation
definitions: , mere According to the Madhyamika-Prasangika school, all phenomena are merely imputed by conception in dependence upon their basis of imputation. Therefore, they are mere imputation and do not exist from their own side in the least. See {{Heart of Wisdom}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Imputed object
definitions: An object imputed by the mind in dependence upon its basis of imputation. See {{Heart of Wisdom}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Inappropriate attention
definitions: A mind that focuses on the qualities of a contaminated object and exaggerates them. It is what actually generates delusions. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Inconsideration
definitions: A deluded mental factor that is the opposite of consideration. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Indestructible drop
definitions: The most subtle drop, which is located at the heart. It is formed from the essence of the white and red drops received from our parents at conception, and encloses the very subtle mind and its mounted wind. These red and white drops do not separate until the time of death, when they open and allow the very subtle mind and its mounted wind to depart to the next life. See {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}} and {{Clear Light of Bliss}}.

entries.title: Indra
definitions: A worldly god. See {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: Inferential cognizer
definitions: A completely reliable cognizer whose object is realized in direct dependence upon a conclusive reason. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Inferential valid cognizer
definitions: A non-deceptive cognizer that realizes its hidden object by depending upon a conclusive reason. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Inherent existence
definitions: An imagined mode of existence whereby phenomena are held to exist from their own side, independent of other phenomena. In reality, all phenomena lack or are empty of inherent existence because they depend upon their parts. See {{Heart of Wisdom}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Initial scope practitioner
definitions: A spiritual practitioner who seeks the happiness of humans and gods. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Innate delusions
definitions: Delusions that are not the product of intellectual speculation, but that arise naturally. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Inner Dakini Land
definitions: A mind of clear light that realizes emptiness directly without a generic image. Synonymous with meaning clear light. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Inner fire
definitions: â€˜Tummoâ€™ in Tibetan. An inner heat located at the centre of the navel channel wheel. See {{Clear Light of Bliss}}.

entries.title: Inner offering
definitions: A Highest Yoga Tantra offering that is produced by transforming ten inner substances into nectar. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Inner winds
definitions: Special subtle winds related to the mind that flow through the channels of our body. Our body and mind cannot function without these winds. See {{Clear Light of Bliss}} and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Intellectually-formed delusions
definitions: Delusions that arise as a result of relying upon incorrect reasoning or mistaken tenets. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Intention
definitions: A mental factor that functions to move its primary mind to the object. It functions to engage the mind in virtuous, non-virtuous, and neutral objects. All bodily and verbal actions are initiated by the mental factor intention. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Intermediate scope practitioner
definitions: A spiritual practitioner who emphasizes the attainment of his or her liberation from samsara. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Intermediate state
definitions: â€˜Bardoâ€™ in Tibetan. The state between death and rebirth. It begins the moment the consciousness leaves the body, and ceases the moment the consciousness enters the body of the next life. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Clear Light of Bliss}}.

entries.title: Investigation
definitions: A mental factor that examines an object to gain an understanding of its gross nature. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Ishvara
definitions: A god who abides in the Land of Controlling Emanations, the highest state of existence within the desire realm. Ishvara has limited, contaminated miracle powers that make him more powerful than other beings in the desire realm. If we entrust ourself to Ishvara we may receive some temporary benefit in this life, such as an increase in wealth or possessions, but wrathful Ishvara is the enemy of those who seek liberation and he interferes with their spiritual progress. He is therefore said to be a type of {{Devaputra}} mara.

entries.title: Jealousy
definitions: A deluded mental factor that feels displeasure when observing othersâ€™ enjoyments, good qualities, or good fortune. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Je Phabongkhapa (AD 1878-1941)
definitions: A great Tibetan Lama who was an emanation of Heruka. Phabongkha Rinpoche was the holder of many lineages of Sutra and Secret Mantra. He was the root Guru of {{Yongdzin Trijang Dorjechang}} (Trijang Rinpoche).

entries.title: Je Tsongkhapa (AD 1357-1419
definitions: An emanation of the Wisdom Buddha Manjushri, whose appearance in fourteenth-century Tibet as a monk, and the holder of the lineage of pure view and pure deeds, was prophesied by Buddha. He spread a very pure Buddhadharma throughout Tibet, showing how to combine the practices of Sutra and Tantra, and how to practise pure Dharma during degenerate times. His tradition later became known as the `Gelugâ€™, or `Ganden Traditionâ€™. See {{Heart Jewel}} and {{Great Treasury of Merit}}:.

entries.title: Joyful Land
definitions: See {{Ganden}}.

entries.title: Kadam Emanation Scripture
definitions: Also known as `Ganden Emanation Scriptureâ€™. A special scripture, the nature of Manjushriâ€™s wisdom, revealed directly to Je Tsongkhapa by Manjushri. It contains instructions on Vajrayana Mahamudra, Offering to the Spiritual Guide (Lama ChÃ¶pa), The Hundreds of Deities of the Joyful Land (Ganden LhagyÃ¤ma), the Migtsema prayer, and six sadhanas of Manjushri. This scripture was not composed in ordinary letters, and only highly realized beings can consult it directly. At first the instructions from this scripture were passed down only by word of mouth from Teacher to disciple, and so the lineage became known as the `Uncommon Whispered Lineage of the Virtuous Traditionâ€™ or the â€˜Ensa Whispered Lineageâ€™. It is also known as the `Uncommon Close Lineageâ€™ because it was revealed directly to Je Tsongkhapa by Manjushri. Later, scholars such as the first [object Object] wrote down the instructions from this scripture in ordinary letters. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}} and {{Heart Jewel}}.

entries.title: Kadampa
definitions: A Tibetan word in which â€˜Kaâ€™ means â€˜wordâ€™ and refers to all Buddhaâ€™s teachings, â€˜damâ€™ refers to Atishaâ€™s special Lamrim instructions known as the â€˜stages of the path to enlightenmentâ€™, and â€˜paâ€™ refers to a follower of Kadampa Buddhism who integrates all the teachings of Buddha that they know into their Lamrim practice. See also {{Kadampa Buddhism}} and {{Kadampa Tradition}}.

entries.title: Kadampa Buddhism
definitions: A Mahayana Buddhist school founded by the great Indian Buddhist Master Atisha (AD 982-1054). See also {{Kadampa}}, {{Kadampa Tradition}}, and {{New Kadampa Tradition}}.

entries.title: Kadampa Tradition
definitions: The pure tradition of Buddhism established by Atisha. Followers of this tradition up to the time of Je Tsongkhapa are known as `Old Kadampasâ€™, and those after the time of Je Tsongkhapa are known as `New Kadampasâ€™. See also {{Kadampa}}, {{Kadampa Buddhism}}, and {{New Kadampa Tradition}}.

entries.title: Kalachakra
definitions: A Highest Yoga Tantra Deity manifested by Buddha Vajradhara.

entries.title: Kalarupa
definitions: A Dharma Protector who is an emanation of Manjushri.

entries.title: Kangyur
definitions: The collection of all the Sutras and Tantras that have been translated from Sanskrit into Tibetan. See also {{TÃ¤ngyur}}.

entries.title: Karma
definitions: Sanskrit word meaning â€˜actionâ€™. Through the force of intention, we perform actions with our body, speech, and mind, and all of these actions produce effects. The effect of virtuous actions is happiness and the effect of negative actions is suffering. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Karmic appearance
definitions: Mere appearance to mind that arises from karma. Everything we perceive when we are dreaming is the result of the ripening of karmic potentials in our mind and has no existence outside of our mind. In a similar way, all the appearances of our waking world are simply the ripening of positive, negative, or neutral karmic imprints in our mind.

entries.title: Kashyapa
definitions: Buddha Kashyapa was the third Buddha to appear in this world and turn the Wheel of Dharma, the previous two being Buddha Krakuchchanda and Buddha Kanakamuni. Buddha Shakyamuni was the fourth, and Buddha Maitreya will be the fifth.

entries.title: Keajra
definitions: Sanskrit word for {{Dakini Land}}, the Pure Land of Buddha Vajrayogini and Buddha Heruka. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}} and {{Essence of Vajrayana}}.

entries.title: KhÃ¤drubje (AD 1385-1438)
definitions: One of the principal disciples of Je Tsongkhapa, who did much to promote the tradition of Je Tsongkhapa after he passed away. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Khandarohi
definitions: One of the eight Goddesses of the body wheel of the Heruka mandala. Her main function is to dispel the obstacles of practitioners. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Khatanga
definitions: A ritual object symbolizing the sixty-two Deities of Heruka.

entries.title: Kusali
definitions: Literally, `Possessor of Virtueâ€™. A name given to great meditators who practise secretly while outwardly appearing as ordinary people. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Lama
definitions: See {{Spiritual Guide}}.

entries.title: Lama Losang Tubwang Dorjechang
definitions: A special manifestation of Je Tsongkhapa revealed directly to the great Yogi Dharmavajra. In this manifestation, Je Tsongkhapa appears as a fully ordained monk wearing a long-eared Panditâ€™s hat, with Buddha Shakyamuni at his heart, and Conqueror Vajradhara at his heart. In the practice of Offering to the Spiritual Guide, we visualize our Spiritual Guide in this aspect. `Lamaâ€™ indicates that he is our Spiritual Guide, `Losangâ€™ that he is Je Tsongkhapa (whose ordained name was Losang Dragpa), `Tubwangâ€™ that he is Buddha Shakyamuni, and `Dorjechangâ€™ that he is Vajradhara. In Tibetan, this aspect of our Spiritual Guide is also known as `je sempa sum tsegâ€™, which means `Je Tsongkhapa, the Unification of Three Holy Beingsâ€™. This indicates that in reality our Spiritual Guide is the same nature as Je Tsongkhapa, Buddha Shakyamuni, and Conqueror Vajradhara. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Lamrim
definitions: A Tibetan term, literally meaning `stages of the pathâ€™. A special arrangement of all Buddhaâ€™s teachings that is easy to understand and put into practice. It reveals all the stages of the path to enlightenment. For a full commentary, see {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Land of the Thirty-three Heavens
definitions: One of the six abodes of desire realm gods. These are, in sequence: Land of the Four Great Kings, Land of the Thirty-three Heavens, Land Without Combat, Joyful Land, Land of Enjoying Emanations, and Land of Controlling Emanations.

entries.title: Langri Tangpa, Geshe (AD 1054-1123)
definitions: A great Kadampa Teacher who was famous for his realization of exchanging self with others. He composed Eight Verses of Training the Mind. See {{Eight Steps to Happiness}}.

entries.title: Laziness
definitions: A deluded mental factor that, motivated by attachment to worldly pleasures or worldly activities, dislikes virtuous activity. There are three types of laziness: laziness arising from attachment to worldly pleasures, laziness arising from attachment to distracting activities, and laziness arising from discouragement. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Learner Superiors
definitions: Superior beings who are still training on the learning paths; that is, Superior beings on either the path of seeing or the path of meditation.

entries.title: Letter
definitions: A vocalization that is a basis for the composition of names and phrases. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Liberation
definitions: â€˜Nirvanaâ€™ in Sanskrit. Complete freedom from samsara and its cause, the delusions. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Life-supporting wind
definitions: An inner energy wind that resides in the heart chakra, and functions to maintain the connection between our mind and body. When its strength diminishes, the connection is broken, and we die. This wind has three levels: gross, subtle, and very subtle. It is the very subtle wind that travels from life to life, supporting the very subtle mind. See {{Living Meaningfully, Dying Joyfully}} and {{Clear Light of Bliss}}.

entries.title: Lineage
definitions: A line of instruction that has been passed down from Spiritual Guide to disciple, with each Spiritual Guide in the line having gained personal experience of the instruction before passing it on to others.

entries.title: Lineage Gurus
definitions: The line of Spiritual Guides through whom a particular instruction has been passed down.

entries.title: Ling Rinpoche (AD 1903-1983)
definitions: The Senior Tutor of the 14th Dalai Lama.

entries.title: Living being
definitions: Synonymous with sentient being (Tib. sem chÃ¤n). Any being who possesses a mind that is contaminated by delusions or their imprints. Both `living beingâ€™ and `sentient beingâ€™ are terms used to distinguish beings whose minds are contaminated by either of these two obstructions from Buddhas, whose minds are completely free from these obstructions.

entries.title: Lochana
definitions: A female Buddha who is the manifestation of the earth element of all Buddhas.

entries.title: Lojong
definitions: A Tibetan term, literally meaning `training the mindâ€™. A special lineage of instructions that came from Buddha Shakyamuni through Manjushri and Shantideva to Atisha and the Kadampa Geshes, which emphasizes the generation of bodhichitta through the practices of equalizing and exchanging self with others combined with taking and giving. See {{Universal Compassion}} and {{Eight Steps to Happiness}}.

entries.title: Long-life god
definitions: An inhabitant of Great Result, one of the fourth form realms. Long-life gods are explained in the Lamrim teachings on the eight unfree states. They experience only two gross minds â€“ one when they realize that they have taken heavenly rebirth and the other when they are about to die. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Lord of Death
definitions: Although the mara of uncontrolled death is not a sentient being, it is personified as the Lord of Death, or â€˜Yamaâ€™. The Lord of Death is depicted in the diagram of the Wheel of Life clutching the wheel between his claws and teeth. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} .

entries.title: Lorig
definitions: Tibetan term for `types of mindâ€™.

entries.title: Losang Dragpa
definitions: â€˜Sumati Kirtiâ€™ in Sanskrit. The ordained name of Je Tsongkhapa. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Lotus posture
definitions: A sitting posture where the soles of both feet are pressed together.

entries.title: Love
definitions: A mind wishing others to be happy. There are three types: affectionate love, cherishing love, and wishing love. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Eight Steps to Happiness}}.

entries.title: Lower realms
definitions: The hell realm, hungry spirit realm, and animal realm. See also {{Samsara}}.

entries.title: Madhyamika
definitions: A Sanskrit term, literally meaning â€˜Middle Wayâ€™. The higher of the two schools of Mahayana tenets. The Madhyamika view was taught by Buddha in the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras during the second turning of the Wheel of Dharma and was subsequently elucidated by Nagarjuna and his followers. There are two divisions of this school, Madhyamika-Svatantrika and Madhyamika-Prasangika, of which the latter is Buddhaâ€™s final view. See {{Meaningful to Behold}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Mahakala
definitions: A Dharma Protector who appears in many different aspects â€“ four-armed, six-armed, four-faced, and so forth.

entries.title: Mahakaruna
definitions: Sanskrit term for `great compassionâ€™, and also an epithet for Buddha Avalokiteshvara.

entries.title: Mahamudra
definitions: A Sanskrit term, literally meaning `great sealâ€™. According to Sutra, this refers to the profound view of emptiness. Since emptiness is the nature of all phenomena, it is called a `sealâ€™, and since a direct realization of emptiness enables us to accomplish the great purpose â€“ complete liberation from the sufferings of samsara â€“ it is also called `greatâ€™. According to Tantra, or Vajrayana, great seal is the union of spontaneous great bliss and emptiness. See {{Mahamudra Tantra}}.

entries.title: Mahasiddha
definitions: Sanskrit term for `Greatly Accomplished Oneâ€™, which is used to refer to Yogis or Yoginis with high attainments.

entries.title: Mahayana
definitions: Sanskrit term for `Great Vehicleâ€™, the spiritual path to great enlightenment. The Mahayana goal is to attain Buddhahood for the benefit of all sentient beings by completely abandoning delusions and their imprints. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Meaningful to Behold}}.

entries.title: Mahayana path
definitions: A clear realization in the mental continuum of a Bodhisattva or a Buddha. There are five Mahayana paths: the Mahayana path of accumulation, the Mahayana path of preparation, the Mahayana path of seeing, the Mahayana path of meditation, and the Mahayana Path of No More Learning. The first four are necessarily in the continuum of a Bodhisattva and the last is necessarily in the continuum of a Buddha. See {{Ocean of Nectar}} and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Maitreya
definitions: The embodiment of the loving kindness of all the Buddhas. At the time of Buddha Shakyamuni he manifested as a Bodhisattva disciple in order to show Buddhaâ€™s disciples how to be perfect Mahayana disciples. In the future, he will manifest as the fifth founding Buddha.

entries.title: Mala
definitions: A rosary used to count recitations of prayers or mantras, usually with one hundred and eight beads. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Mamaki
definitions: A female Buddha who is the manifestation of the water element of all Buddhas.

entries.title: Mandala
definitions: Usually the celestial mansion in which a Tantric Deity abides, or the environment or Deities of a Buddhaâ€™s Pure Land. Sometimes it is used to refer to the essence of an element, for example `wind mandalaâ€™. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}} and {{Essence of Vajrayana}}.

entries.title: Mandala offering
definitions: An offering of the entire universe visualized as a Pure Land, with all its inhabitants as pure beings. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}} and {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Manifest object
definitions: An object whose initial realization by a valid cognizer does not depend upon logical reasons. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Manjushri
definitions: The embodiment of the wisdom of all the Buddhas. At the time of Buddha Shakyamuni he manifested as a Bodhisattva disciple in order to show Buddhaâ€™s disciples how to be perfect Mahayana disciples. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}} and {{Heart Jewel}}.

entries.title: Mantra
definitions: A Sanskrit word, literally meaning `mind protectionâ€™. Mantra protects the mind from ordinary appearances and conceptions. There are four types of mantra: mantras that are mind, mantras that are inner wind, mantras that are sound, and mantras that are form. In general, there are three types of mantra recitation: verbal recitation, mental recitation, and vajra recitation. See {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Mara
definitions: â€˜Maraâ€™ is Sanskrit for â€˜demonâ€™, and refers to anything that obstructs the attainment of liberation or enlightenment. There are four principal types of mara: the mara of the delusions, the mara of contaminated aggregates, the mara of uncontrolled death, and the Devaputra maras. Of these, only the last are actual sentient beings. The principal Devaputra mara is wrathful Ishvara, the highest of the desire realm gods, who inhabits Land of Controlling Emanations. A Buddha is called a `Conquerorâ€™ because he or she has conquered all four types of mara. See {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: Marpa (1012-1096)
definitions: Marpa Lotsawa, or Marpa the translator, was a great lay Tantric Yogi and the Spiritual Guide of Milrepa. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Meaning clear light
definitions: A mind of clear light that realizes emptiness directly without a generic image. Synonymous with inner Dakini Land. See Clear Light of Bliss.

entries.title: Medicine Buddha
definitions: Buddhaâ€™s Truth Body appears in the form of Medicine Buddha, with a blue-coloured body, one face and two hands, holding a jewelled bowl and a medicinal plant. His function is to release living beings from outer and inner sickness by bestowing blessings upon them.

entries.title: Meditation
definitions: Meditation is a mind that concentrates on a virtuous object, and is a mental action that is the main cause of mental peace. There are two types of meditation â€“ analytical meditation and placement meditation. When we use our imagination, mindfulness, and powers of reasoning to find our object of meditation, this is analytical meditation. When we find our object and hold it single-pointedly, this is placement meditation. There are different types of object. Some, such as impermanence or emptiness, are objects apprehended by the mind. Others, such as love, compassion, and renunciation, are actual states of mind. We engage in analytical meditation until the specific object that we seek appears clearly to our mind or until the particular state of mind that we wish to generate arises. This object or state of mind is our object of placement meditation. See also {{Analytical meditation}} and {{Placement meditation}}. See {{The New Meditation Handbook}}.

entries.title: Meditation break
definitions: See {{Subsequent attainment}}.

entries.title: Meditative equipoise
definitions: Single-pointed concentration on a virtuous object such as emptiness. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Mental awareness
definitions: All minds are included within the five sense awarenesses and mental awareness. Mental awareness is an awareness that is developed in dependence upon its uncommon dominant condition, a mental power. There are two types of mental awareness: conceptual mental awareness and non-conceptual mental awareness. Conceptual mental awareness and conceptual mind are synonyms. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Mental continuum
definitions: The continuum of a personâ€™s mind that has no beginning and no end.

entries.title: Mental direct perceiver
definitions: A direct perceiver that is generated in dependence upon its uncommon dominant condition, a mental power. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Mental excitement
definitions: A deluded mental factor that wanders to any object of attachment. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Mental factor
definitions: A cognizer that principally apprehends a particular attribute of an object. There are fifty-one specific mental factors. Each moment of mind comprises a primary mind and various mental factors. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Mental image
definitions: See {{Generic image}}.

entries.title: Mentality
definitions: Mentality, primary mind, and consciousness are synonyms.

entries.title: Mental power
definitions: A mind that principally functions directly to produce the uncommon aspect of a mental awareness. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Mental sinking
definitions: A mental factor that destroys the clarity of concentration and its firm hold upon the object. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Mental stabilization
definitions: Generally, the terms â€˜mental stabilizationâ€™ and â€˜concentrationâ€™ are interchangeable. More specifically, the term â€˜concentrationâ€™ is used to refer to the nature of concentration, which is single-pointedness, and the term â€˜mental stabilizationâ€™ is used to refer to the function of concentration, which is stability. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Meaningful to Behold}}.

entries.title: Mental suppleness
definitions: A flexibility of mind induced by virtuous concentration. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Mere appearance
definitions: All phenomena are mere appearance because they are imputed by mind in dependence upon a suitable basis of imputation appearing to mind. The word â€˜mereâ€™ excludes any possibility of inherent existence. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Merit
definitions: The good fortune created by virtuous actions. It is the potential power to increase our good qualities and produce happiness.

entries.title: Middle way
definitions: â€˜Madhyamikaâ€™ in Sanskrit. The correct view of emptiness avoids both extremes and therefore emptiness is called the â€˜middle wayâ€™. The higher of the two schools of Mahayana tenets. See also {{Madhyamika}}.

entries.title: Migrator
definitions: A being within samsara who migrates from one uncontrolled rebirth to another.

entries.title: Migtsema
definitions: A special prayer of praise and requests to Je Tsongkhapa composed by Manjushri in the Kadam Emanation Scripture. The prayer appears in various forms, such as the nine-line and five-line versions. This prayer is very blessed, and those who recite it with faith are able to accomplish great results. See {{Heart Jewel}}.

entries.title: Milarepa (1040-1123)
definitions: A great Tibetan Buddhist meditator and disciple of Marpa, celebrated for his beautiful songs of realization.

entries.title: Mind
definitions: That which is clarity and cognizes. Mind is clarity because it always lacks form and because it possesses the actual power to perceive objects. Mind cognizes because its function is to know or perceive objects. See {{Understanding the Mind}}, {{Mahamudra Tantra}}, and {{Clear Light of Bliss}}.

entries.title: Mind of enlightenment
definitions: See {{Bodhichitta}}.

entries.title: Mindfulness
definitions: A mental factor that functions not to forget the object realized by the primary mind. See {{Understanding the Mind}} and {{Clear Light of Bliss}}.

entries.title: Miracle powers
definitions: See {{Clairvoyance}}.

entries.title: Miserliness
definitions: A deluded mental factor that, motivated by desirous attachment, holds onto things tightly and does not want to part with them. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Mistaken appearance
definitions: All minds of sentient beings, except for the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of a Superior being observing emptiness, are mistaken awarenesses because their objects appear to be truly existent; and this appearance is a mistaken appearance that is by nature an obstruction to omniscience. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Mistaken awareness/mind
definitions: A mind that is mistaken with respect to its appearing object. Although all minds of ordinary beings are mistaken, they are not necessarily wrong. A wrong mind is a mind that is mistaken with respect to its engaged object. Thus our eye awareness perceiving this page is a mistaken mind because the page appears as inherently existent, but it is a correct mind because it correctly apprehends the page as a page. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.
