entries.title: Moral discipline
definitions: A virtuous mental determination to abandon any fault, or a bodily or verbal action motivated by such a determination. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Meaningful to Behold}}.

entries.title: Mother Tantra
definitions: A Tantra that principally reveals methods for attaining clear light.

entries.title: Mount Meru
definitions: According to Buddhist cosmology, a divine mountain that stands at the centre of the universe. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Mudra
definitions: Generally, the Sanskrit word for `sealâ€™, as in `Mahamudraâ€™, the `great sealâ€™. More specifically, `mudraâ€™ is used to refer to a consort, as in `action mudraâ€™ or `wisdom mudraâ€™; and to hand gestures used in Tantric rituals.

entries.title: Mundane happiness
definitions: The limited happiness that can be found within samsara, such as the happiness of humans and gods.

entries.title: Mundane paths
definitions: Contaminated actions that lead to samsaric rebirth. There are two types: the ten non-virtuous actions that lead to the lower realms, and the ten virtuous actions and contaminated concentrations that lead to the higher realms.

entries.title: Nada
definitions: A three-curved line that appears above certain seed-letters.

entries.title: Naga
definitions: A non-human being not normally visible to human beings. Their upper half is said to be human, their lower half serpent. Nagas usually live in the oceans of the world but they sometimes inhabit land in the region of rocks and trees. They are very powerful, some being benevolent and some malevolent. Many diseases, known as `naga diseasesâ€™, are caused by nagas and can only be cured through performing certain naga rituals.

entries.title: Nagarjuna
definitions: A great Indian Buddhist scholar and meditation master who revived the Mahayana in the first century AD by bringing to light the teachings on the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras. Nagarjunaâ€™s extraordinary life and works were prophesied by Buddha Shakyamuni. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Nalanda Monastery
definitions: A great seat of Buddhist learning and practice in ancient India.

entries.title: Name
definitions: An object of hearing that principally expresses the name of any phenomenon. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Namo
definitions: A Sanskrit word of homage and respect.

entries.title: Naropa (AD 1016-1100)
definitions: An Indian Mahasiddha and a lineage Guru in the Highest Yoga Tantra practice of Vajrayogini. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Nature Body
definitions: The ultimate nature of a Buddhaâ€™s mind. Also known as `Entity Bodyâ€™. See also Truth Body. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}, {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}, and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Negated object
definitions: An object explicitly negated by a mind realizing a negative phenomenon. In meditation on emptiness, or lack of inherent existence, it refers to inherent existence. Also known as {{object of negation}}.

entries.title: Negative phenomenon
definitions: An object that is realized through the mind explicitly eliminating a negated object. There are two types of negative phenomenon: affirming negatives and non-affirming negatives. An affirming negative is a negative phenomenon realized by a mind that eliminates its negated object while realizing another phenomenon. A non-affirming negative is a negative phenomenon realized by a mind that merely eliminates its negated object without realizing another phenomenon. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Never Returner
definitions: See {{Hearer}}.

entries.title: New Kadampa Tradition (
definitions: The union of Kadampa Buddhist Centres, an international association of study and meditation centres that follow the pure tradition of Mahayana Buddhism derived from the Buddhist meditator and scholar Je Tsongkhapa, introduced into the West by the Buddhist teacher Venerable Geshe Kelsang Gyatso.

entries.title: Nine mental abidings
definitions: Nine levels of concentration leading to tranquil abiding: placing the mind, continual placement, replacement, close placement, controlling, pacifying, completely pacifying, single-pointedness, and placement in equipoise. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Meaningful to Behold}}.

entries.title: Nirvana
definitions: Sanskrit word for â€˜liberationâ€™. Complete freedom from samsara and its cause, the delusions. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Nominal truth
definitions: The objects we know simply by using their names without the need for analysis, such as our self, our body, and other things that we use in our everyday life. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Non-affirming negative
definitions: See {{Negative phenomenon}}.

entries.title: Non-alertness
definitions: A deluded mental factor that, being unable to distinguish faults from non-faults, causes us to develop faults. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Non-ascertaining perceiver
definitions: A cognizer to which a phenomenon that is its engaged object appears clearly without being ascertained. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Non-associated compounded phenomenon
definitions: Any impermanent phenomenon that is neither form nor mind, such as person, life, time, and potentiality.

entries.title: Non-attachment
definitions: A mental factor that functions as the direct opponent of attachment. See {{Universal Compassion}} and {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Non-conceptual mind
definitions: A cognizer to which its object appears clearly without being mixed with a generic image. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Non-conscientiousness
definitions: A deluded mental factor that wishes to engage in non-virtuous actions without restraint. See â€œUnderstanding the Mind.

entries.title: Non-existent
definitions: Traditional examples of non-existents are a horn on a rabbitâ€™s head and a child of a barren woman. A horn on a rabbitâ€™s head, for example, is not established by any valid mind and is consequently a non-existent rather than a conventional (or ultimate) truth. See {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: Non-fabricated bodhichitta
definitions: See {{Spontaneous bodhichitta}}.

entries.title: Non-faith
definitions: A deluded mental factor that is the opposite of faith. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Non-harmfulness
definitions: A mental factor that wishes sentient beings not to suffer. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Non-hatred
definitions: A mental factor that functions as the direct opponent of hatred. See {{Universal Compassion}} and {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Non-ignorance
definitions: A mental factor that functions as the direct opponent of ignorance. See {{Universal Compassion}} and {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Non-valid cognizer
definitions: A cognizer that is deceptive with respect to its engaged object. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Non-virtue
definitions: A phenomenon that functions as a main cause of suffering. It can refer to non-virtuous minds, non-virtuous actions, non-virtuous imprints, or the ultimate non-virtue of samsara. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Non-virtuous actions
definitions: Paths that lead to the lower realms. Non-virtuous actions are countless, but most of them are included within the ten: killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, divisive speech, hurtful speech, idle gossip, covetousness, malice, and holding wrong views. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: NyungnÃ¤
definitions: A fasting and purification retreat in conjunction with Eleven-faced Avalokiteshvara.

entries.title: Object of negation
definitions: An object explicitly negated by a mind realizing a negative phenomenon. In meditation on emptiness, or lack of inherent existence, it refers to inherent existence. Also known as {{negated object}}.

entries.title: Object-possessor
definitions: A functioning thing that expresses or cognizes an object. It includes expressive sounds, persons, and minds. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Object to be abandoned
definitions: Any object that is the principal cause of suffering, such as ignorance, other delusions, or non-virtuous actions.

entries.title: Observed object
definitions: Any object upon which the mind is focused. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Obstructions to liberation
definitions: Obstructions that prevent the attainment of liberation. All delusions, such as ignorance, attachment, and anger, together with their seeds, are obstructions to liberation. Also called {{delusion-obstructions}}.

entries.title: Obstructions to omniscience
definitions: The imprints of delusions, which prevent simultaneous and direct realization of all phenomena. Only Buddhas have overcome these obstructions.

entries.title: Offering
definitions: That which delights the holy beings.

entries.title: Offering to the Spiritual Guide
definitions: Lama ChÃ¶pa in Tibetan. A special Guru yoga of Je Tsongkhapa, in which our Spiritual Guide is visualized in the aspect of Lama Losang Tubwang Dorjechang. The instruction for this practice was revealed by Buddha Manjushri in the Kadam Emanation Scripture and written down by the first Panchen Lama (AD 1569-1662). It is an essential preliminary practice for Vajrayana Mahamudra. See also Lama Losang Tubwang Dorjechang. For a full commentary, see {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Once Returner
definitions: See {{Hearer}}.

entries.title: Opponent powers
definitions: See {{Four opponent powers}}â€œ.

entries.title: Oral transmission
definitions: The granting of blessings through verbal instruction. Receiving these blessings is essential for gaining authentic realizations. All the root texts and their commentaries have been passed down in a pure, unbroken lineage from Teacher to disciple from the time of Buddha Shakyamuni down to the present day. It is customary at the end of a teaching for the Teacher to recite all the words of the text, just as he or she heard them from his or her own Teacher. A disciple is not considered to have received a teaching until he or she has heard all the words from the mouth of a qualified Spiritual Guide. A teaching that has been received in this way is completely pure, and it carries the blessing of all the lineage Gurus who transmitted the same teachings in the past.

entries.title: Ordinary appearance and conception
definitions: Ordinary appearance is any appearance that is due to an impure mind, and ordinary conception is any mind that conceives things as ordinary. According to Tantra, ordinary appearances are obstructions to omniscience and ordinary conceptions are obstructions to liberation. See {{Mahamudra Tantra}} and {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Ordinary being
definitions: Anyone who has not realized emptiness directly.

entries.title: Ordinary conception
definitions: See {{Ordinary appearance and conception}}.

entries.title: Outer Dakini Land
definitions: The Pure Land of Vajrayogini. See

entries.title: Parshavajra
definitions: The emptiness of tangible objects appearing in the form of an offering goddess. see {{Great Treasury of Merit}} and {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Path/Spiritual path
definitions: An exalted awareness conjoined with non-fabricated, or spontaneous, renunciation. Spiritual path, spiritual ground, spiritual vehicle, and exalted awareness are synonyms. See also {{Ground/Spiritual ground}} ground. See {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Patience
definitions: A virtuous determination to forbear harm, suffering, or profound Dharma. See {{How to Solve Our Human Problems}}.

links.title: How to Solve Our Human Problems

entries.title: Perfection of wisdom
definitions: Any wisdom maintained by bodhichitta motivation. See {{Heart of Wisdom}}, {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}, and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Perfection of Wisdom Sutras
definitions: Sutras of the second turning of the Wheel of Dharma, in which Buddha revealed his final view of the ultimate nature of all phenomena â€“ emptiness of inherent existence. See {{Heart of Wisdom}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Perfection Vehicle
definitions: The Mahayana Sutra Vehicle.

entries.title: Performance Tantra
definitions: See {{Four classes of Tantra}}.

entries.title: Permanent phenomenon
definitions: Phenomena are either permanent or impermanent. A permanent phenomenon is a phenomenon that does not depend upon causes and that does not disintegrate moment by moment. It lacks the characteristics of production, abiding, and disintegration.

entries.title: Person
definitions: An I imputed in dependence upon any of the five aggregates. Person, being, self, and I are synonyms. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Phabongkha Rinpoche
definitions: See {{Je Phabongkhapa}}.

entries.title: Phenomena source
definitions: A phenomenon that appears only to mental awareness. This can include form that appears exclusively to mental awareness, such as a dream mountain that appears to a dream eye awareness, which is called â€˜form that is a phenomena sourceâ€™. Phenomena source is also the name given to Buddha Vajrayoginiâ€™s mandala, which is symbolic of the source of all phenomena, emptiness. See {{Understanding the Mind}}, {{Ocean of Nectar}}, and {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Phrase
definitions: An object of hearing that indicates a meaning by connecting a name with a predicate. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Physical suppleness
definitions: A light and flexible tactile object within our body that develops when meditation causes a pure wind to pervade the body.

entries.title: Placement meditation
definitions: Single-pointed concentration on a virtuous object. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{The New Meditation Handbook}}.

entries.title: Positive phenomenon
definitions: See {{Affirmative phenomenon}}.

entries.title: Powa
definitions: See {{Transference of consciousness}}.

entries.title: Prasangika
definitions: See {{Madhyamika}}.

entries.title: Pratimoksha
definitions: Sanskrit term for `personal liberationâ€™. See {{The Bodhisattva Vow}}.

entries.title: Pratimoksha vow
definitions: â€˜Pratimokshaâ€™ is the Sanskrit term for â€˜personal liberationâ€™, and so a Pratimoksha vow is a vow that is motivated mainly by the wish to attain personal liberation. There are eight types of Pratimoksha vow. See {{The Bodhisattva Vow}}.

entries.title: Preceptor
definitions: A Spiritual Guide who give us vows or commitments to observe.

entries.title: Precious human life
definitions: A life that has eight special freedoms and ten special endowments that make it an ideal opportunity for training the mind in all the stages of the path to enlightenment. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Preparatory practices
definitions: Practices that prepare the mind for successful meditation, such as purifying the mind, accumulating merit, and receiving blessings. See also {{Essence of Good Fortune}} See {{Eight Steps to Happiness}}, {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{The New Meditation Handbook}}.

entries.title: Preliminary guide
definitions: Altogether there are nine preliminary guides, so called because by engaging in them we are guided to the actual spiritual paths of Tantra. The four main ones are: (1) the guide of going for refuge and generating bodhichitta, (2) the guide of meditation and recitation of Vajrasattva, (3) the guide of Guru yoga, and (4) the guide of making mandala offerings. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Pretension
definitions: A deluded mental factor that, motivated by attachment to wealth or reputation, wishes to pretend that we possess qualities that we do not possess. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Pride
definitions: A deluded mental factor that, through considering and exaggerating oneâ€™s own good qualities or possessions, feels arrogant. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Primary mind
definitions: A cognizer that principally apprehends the mere entity of an object. Synonymous with consciousness. There are six primary minds: eye consciousness, ear consciousness, nose consciousness, tongue consciousness, body consciousness, and mental consciousness. Each moment of mind comprises a primary mind and various mental factors. A primary mind and its accompanying mental factors are the same entity but have different functions. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Profound path
definitions: The profound path includes all the wisdom practices that lead to a direct realization of emptiness and ultimately to the Truth Body of a Buddha. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Proponents of things
definitions: The Vaibhashika, Sautrantika, and Chittamatra Buddhist schools are known as â€˜proponents of thingsâ€™ because they assert that things are truly existent. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Prostration
definitions: An action of showing respect with body, speech, or mind. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{The Bodhisattva Vow}}.

entries.title: Puja
definitions: A ceremony in which offerings and other acts of devotion are performed in front of holy beings.

entries.title: Pure Dakini Land
definitions: See {{Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Pure Land
definitions: A pure environment in which there are no true sufferings. There are many Pure Lands. For example, Tushita is the Pure Land of Buddha Maitreya, Sukhavati is the Pure Land of Buddha Amitabha, and Keajra is the Pure Land of Buddha Vajrayogini and Buddha Heruka. See {{Living Meaningfully, Dying Joyfully}}.

entries.title: Purification
definitions: Generally, any practice that leads to the attainment of a pure body, speech, or mind. More specifically, a practice for purifying negative karma by means of the four opponent powers. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}, {{The Bodhisattva Vow}}, {{Universal Compassion}}, and {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Rasavajra
definitions: The emptiness of taste appearing in the form of an offering goddess. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}}, {{Great Treasury of Merit}}, and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Ratnasambhava
definitions: The manifestation of the aggregate of feeling of all Buddhas. He has a yellow-coloured body.

entries.title: Realization
definitions: A stable and non-mistaken experience of a virtuous object that directly protects us from suffering.

entries.title: Re-cognizer
definitions: A cognizer that realizes what has already been realized through the force of a previous valid cognizer. See {{Heart of Wisdom}} and {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Refuge
definitions: Actual protection. To go for refuge to Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha means to have faith in these Three Jewels and to rely upon them for protection from all fears and suffering. See

entries.title: Regret
definitions: A mental factor that feels remorse for actions done in the past. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Rejoicing
definitions: A joyful mind, free of jealousy or pride, that takes delight in the virtuous actions of ourself or others. See {{Meaningful to Behold}}.

entries.title: Renunciation
definitions: The wish to be released from samsara. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Resentment
definitions: A deluded mental factor that maintains the continuum of anger without forgetting it, and wishes to retaliate. See {{How to Solve Our Human Problems}} and {{Understanding the Mind}}.

links.title: How to Solve Our Human Problems

entries.title: Retreat
definitions: A period of time during which we impose various restrictions on our actions of body, speech, and mind so as to be able to concentrate more fully on a particular spiritual practice. See also {{Close retreat}}. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}} and {{Heart Jewel}}.

entries.title: Root Guru
definitions: The principal Spiritual Guide from whom we have received the empowerments, instructions, and oral transmissions of our main practice. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}}, {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}, and {{Heart Jewel}}. Guide to the Middle Way a classic Mahayana Buddhist text composed by the great Indian Buddhist Yogi and scholar Chandrakirti, which provides a comprehensive explanation of the Madhyamika-Prasangika view of emptiness as taught in the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras. For a translation and full commentary, see {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Root mind
definitions: The very subtle mind located at the centre of the heart channel wheel. It is known as the â€˜root mindâ€™ because all other minds arise from it and dissolve back into it. See {{Mahamudra Tantra}}.

entries.title: Rupavajra
definitions: The emptiness of form appearing in the form of an offering goddess. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}}:, and {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Sadhana
definitions: A ritual prayer that is the special method for attainment, usually associated with a Tantric Deity.

entries.title: Samantabhadra
definitions: Sanskrit name for â€˜All Good Oneâ€™, a Bodhisattva renowned for his extensive offerings. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Samkhya
definitions: A non-Buddhist school, the oldest of the Brahmaic schools. See {{Ocean of Nectar}} and {{Meaningful to Behold}}.

entries.title: Samsara
definitions: The cycle of uncontrolled death and rebirth, or the cycle of twelve dependent-related links. Sometimes known as â€˜cyclic existenceâ€™. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

This can be understood in two ways â€“ as uninterrupted rebirth without freedom or control, or as the aggregates of a being who has taken such a rebirth. Samsara, sometimes known as â€˜cyclic existenceâ€™, is characterized by suffering and dissatisfaction. There are six realms of samsara. Listed in ascending order according to the type of karma that causes rebirth in them, they are the realms of the hell beings, hungry spirits, animals, human beings, demi-gods, and gods. The first three are lower realms or unhappy migrations, and the second three are higher realms or happy migrations. Although from the point of view of the karma that causes rebirth there, the god realm is the highest realm in samsara, the human realm is said to be the most fortunate realm because it provides the best conditions for attaining liberation and enlightenment. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Sangha
definitions: According to the Vinaya tradition, any community of four or more fully ordained monks or nuns. In general, ordained or lay people who take Bodhisattva vows or Tantric vows can also be said to be Sangha. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Sangha Jewel
definitions: See {{Three Jewels}}.

entries.title: Sanskrit vowels and consonants
definitions: The source of the three letters [object Object], and of all mantras in general, is the sixteen Sanskrit vowels and the thirty-four Sanskrit consonants. The sixteen vowels are: [object Object]. The thirty-four consonants are: [object Object].

entries.title: Saraha
definitions: One of the first Mahasiddhas, and the Teacher of Nagarjuna. See {{Essence of Vajrayana}}.

entries.title: Sautrantika
definitions: The higher of the two schools of Hinayana tenets. This school accepts both self-cognizers and external objects to be truly existent. See {{Meaningful to Behold}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Schools of Buddhist philosophy/tenets
definitions: Four philosophical views taught by Buddha according to the inclinations and dispositions of disciples. They are the Vaibhashika, Sautrantika, Chittamatra, and Madhyamika schools. The first two are Hinayana schools and the second two are Mahayana schools. They are studied in sequence, the lower tenets being the means by which the higher ones are understood. See {{Meaningful to Behold}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Secret Mantra
definitions: Synonymous with Tantra. Secret Mantra teachings are distinguished from Sutra teachings in that they reveal methods for training the mind by bringing the future result, or Buddhahood, into the present path. Secret Mantra is the supreme path to full enlightenment. The term `Mantraâ€™ indicates that it is Buddhaâ€™s special instruction for protecting our mind from ordinary appearances and conceptions. Practitioners of Secret Mantra overcome ordinary appearances and conceptions by visualizing their body, environment, enjoyments, and deeds as those of a Buddha. The term `Secretâ€™ indicates that the practices are to be done in private, and that they can be practised only by those who have received a Tantric empowerment. See {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Sectarianism
definitions: At the same time as cherishing our own tradition, we should respect all other traditions and the right of each individual to follow the tradition of their choosing. This approach leads to harmony and tolerance. It is mixing different religious traditions that causes sectarianism. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Seed-letter
definitions: The sacred letter from which a Deity is generated. Each Deity has a particular seed-letter. For example, the seed-letter of Manjushri is [object Object], of Tara is [object Object], of Vajrayogini is [object Object], and of Heruka is [object Object]. To accomplish Tantric realizations, we need to recognize that Deities and their seed-letters are the same nature.

entries.title: Seed of delusion
definitions: The seed of a delusion is the potentiality for that delusion to arise; it is the substantial cause of the delusion. Until we have finally abandoned a delusion, the seed of that delusion will remain within our mind, even when the delusion itself is not manifest. Seeds of delusions can be eradicated only by the wisdom directly realizing emptiness. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Segyu Lineage
definitions: The lineage of the instructions on Ganden LhagyÃ¤ma, or The Hundreds of Deities of the Joyful Land, passed from Je Tsongkhapa to Je Sherab Senge, PaldÃ¤n Sangpo, KhÃ¤drub Sangye Yeshe, and so on down to our present Teachers. This lineage is so called because the original Gurus came from a region of Tibet called Se. See also {{Hundreds of Deities of the Joyful Land}}. See {{Heart Jewel}}.

links.title: Hundreds of Deities of the Joyful Land

entries.title: Self-cherishing
definitions: A mental attitude that considers oneself to be supremely important and precious. It is regarded as a principal object to be abandoned by Bodhisattvas. See {{Eight Steps to Happiness}} and {{Meaningful to Behold}}.

entries.title: Self-cognizer
definitions: A consciousness that experiences itself. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Self-grasping
definitions: A conceptual mind that holds any phenomenon to be inherently existent. The mind of self-grasping gives rise to all other delusions, such as anger and attachment. It is the root cause of all suffering and dissatisfaction. See {{Heart of Wisdom}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Selflessness
definitions: See {{Emptiness}}.

entries.title: Self-satisfaction
definitions: A deluded mental factor that observes our own physical beauty, wealth, or other good qualities, and being concerned only with these, has no interest in spiritual development. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Sense awareness
definitions: All minds are included within sense awareness and mental awareness. The definition of sense awareness is an awareness that is developed in dependence upon its uncommon dominant condition, a sense power possessing form. There are five types of sense awareness: eye awareness, ear awareness, nose awareness, tongue awareness, and body awareness. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Sense direct perceiver
definitions: A direct perceiver that is generated in dependence upon its uncommon dominant condition, a sense power possessing form. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Sense of shame
definitions: A mental factor that functions to avoid inappropriate actions for reasons that concern oneself. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Sense power
definitions: An inner power located in the very centre of a sense organ that functions directly to produce a sense awareness. There are five sense powers, one for each type of sense awareness â€“ the eye awareness and so forth. They are sometimes known as `sense powers possessing formâ€™. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Sentient being
definitions: â€˜Sem chÃ¤nâ€™ in Tibetan. Any being who possesses a mind that is contaminated by delusions or their imprints. Both `sentient beingâ€™ and `living beingâ€™ are terms used to distinguish beings whose minds are contaminated by either of these two obstructions from Buddhas, whose minds are completely free from these obstructions.

entries.title: Seven limbs
definitions: Special practices for purifying negativity and accumulating merit. They are prostration, offering, confession, rejoicing, beseeching the holy beings not to pass away, requesting the turning of the Wheel of Dharma, and dedication. They are called `limbsâ€™ because they provide support for the main body of our practice, which is the actual meditations on the paths of Sutra and Tantra. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Sevenfold cause and effect
definitions: A method for generating bodhichitta in which affectionate love is developed primarily by recognizing all sentient beings as our mothers and remembering their kindness. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Meaningful to Behold}}.

entries.title: Seven-point posture of Vairochana
definitions: A special posture for meditation, in which parts of our body adopt a particular position: (1) sitting on a comfortable cushion with the legs crossed in the vajra posture (in which the feet are placed upon the opposite thighs), (2) the back straight, (3) the head inclined slightly forward, (4) the eyes remaining open slightly, gazing down the nose, (5) the shoulders level, (6) the mouth gently closed, and (7) the right hand placed upon the left, palms up, four finger widths below the navel with the two thumbs touching just above the navel.

entries.title: Shakyamuni
definitions: See {{Buddha Shakyamuni}}.

entries.title: Shamelessness
definitions: A deluded mental factor that is the opposite of sense of shame. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Shantideva (AD 687-763)
definitions: A great Indian Buddhist scholar and meditation master. He composed {{Guide to the Bodhisattvaâ€™s Way of Life}}. See {{Meaningful to Behold}}.

links.title: Guide to the Bodhisattvaâ€™s Way of Life

entries.title: Shaptavajra
definitions: The emptiness of sound appearing in the form of an offering goddess. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}} and {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Shariputra
definitions: One of Buddha Shakyamuniâ€™s principal disciples. He has the aspect of a Hinayana Foe Destroyer. See {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: Siddhi
definitions: See {{Attainment}}.

entries.title: Sindhura
definitions: A red powder from any of the Twenty-four Auspicious Places of Heruka. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Six perfections
definitions: The perfections of giving, moral discipline, patience, effort, mental stabilization, and wisdom. They are called `perfectionsâ€™ because they are motivated by bodhichitta. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Meaningful to Behold}}.

entries.title: Six powers
definitions: The five sense powers and the mental power. A sense power is an inner power located in the very centre of a sense organ that functions directly to produce a sense awareness. There are five sense powers, one for each type of sense awareness. A mental power is a mind that principally functions directly to produce the uncommon aspect of a mental awareness. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Six realms
definitions: There are six realms of samsara. Listed in ascending order according to the type of karma that causes rebirth in them, they are the realms of the hell beings, hungry spirits, animals, human beings, demi-gods, and gods. The first three are lower realms or unhappy migrations, and the second three are higher realms or happy migrations. Although from the point of view of the karma that causes rebirth there, the god realm is the highest realm in samsara, the human realm is said to be the most fortunate realm because it provides the best conditions for attaining liberation and enlightenment. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Sixteen characteristics of the four noble truths
definitions: Buddha taught that each of the four noble truths has four special characteristics. The four characteristics of true sufferings are: impermanent, suffering, empty, and selfless. The four characteristics of true origins are: cause, origin, strong producer, and condition. The four characteristics of true cessations are: cessation, peace, supreme attainment, and definite abandoner. The four characteristics of true paths are: path, antidote, accomplisher, and definite abandoning. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Sixty-two Deities of Heruka
definitions: There are sixty-two Deities in Herukaâ€™s mandala: six Deities of the great bliss wheel, sixteen Deities of the heart wheel, sixteen Deities of the speech wheel, sixteen Deities of the body wheel, and eight Deities of the commitment wheel. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Sleep
definitions: A mental factor that is developed through dullness or its imprints and that functions to gather the sense awarenesses inwards. See {{Clear Light of Bliss}} and {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Solitary peace
definitions: A Hinayana nirvana.

entries.title: Solitary Realizer
definitions: One of two types of Hinayana practitioner. Also known as `Solitary Conquerorâ€™. Both Hearers and Solitary Realizers are Hinayanists, but they differ in their motivation, behaviour, merit, and wisdom. In all these respects, Solitary Realizers are superior to Hearers. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Spiritual Guide
definitions: â€˜Guruâ€™ in Sanskrit, â€˜Lamaâ€™ in Tibetan. A Teacher who guides us along the spiritual path. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Spite
definitions: A deluded mental factor that, motivated by resentment or aggression, wishes to speak harshly. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Spontaneous bodhichitta Actual bodhichitta
definitions: Also known as `non-fabricated bodhichittaâ€™, this mind arises spontaneously day and night. At first we generate an artificial, or fabricated, bodhichitta at certain times by contemplating the suffering of others and so forth, and this acts as the foundation for developing actual bodhichitta.

entries.title: Spontaneous great bliss
definitions: A special bliss that is produced by the drops melting inside the central channel. It is attained by gaining control over the inner winds. See {{Clear Light of Bliss}} and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Stages of the path
definitions: â€˜Lamrimâ€™ in Tibetan. A special arrangement of all Buddhaâ€™s teachings that is easy to understand and put into practice. It reveals all the stages of the path to enlightenment. For a full commentary, see {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Stream Enterer
definitions: See {{Hearer}}.

entries.title: Stupa
definitions: A symbolic representation of Buddhaâ€™s mind.

entries.title: Subsequent attainment
definitions: The period between meditation sessions. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Substantial cause
definitions: Main cause.

entries.title: Subtle impermanence
definitions: See {{Impermanent phenomenon}}.

entries.title: Sugata
definitions: Another Sanskrit term for a Buddha. It indicates that Buddhas have attained a state of immaculate and indestructible bliss.

entries.title: Sukhavati
definitions: Sanskrit term for â€˜Pure Land of Blissâ€™ or â€˜Blissful Landâ€™ â€“ the Pure Land of Buddha Amitabha.

entries.title: Superior being
definitions: â€˜Aryaâ€™ in Sanskrit. A being who has a direct realization of emptiness. There are Hinayana Superiors and Mahayana Superiors.

entries.title: Superior intention
definitions: Motivated by great compassion, the determination to take personal responsibility to release others from suffering and lead them to perfect happiness. See Joyful Path of Good Fortune.

entries.title: Superior seeing
definitions: A special wisdom that sees its object clearly, and that is maintained by tranquil abiding and the special suppleness that is induced by investigation. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Suppleness
definitions: There are two types of suppleness, mental and physical. Mental suppleness is a flexibility of mind induced by virtuous concentration. Physical suppleness is a light and flexible tactile object within our body that develops when meditation causes a pure wind to pervade the body.

entries.title: Supramundane happiness
definitions: The pure happiness of liberation and enlightenment.

entries.title: Supramundane path
definitions: Any path leading to liberation or enlightenment â€“ for example, the realizations of renunciation, bodhichitta, and the correct view of emptiness. Strictly speaking, only Superior beings possess supramundane paths. See {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Supreme attainments
definitions: See {{Attainment}}.

entries.title: Supreme Emanation Body
definitions: A special Emanation Body displaying the thirty-two major signs and eighty minor indications that can be seen by ordinary beings only if they have very pure karma. See also {{Buddhaâ€™s bodies}} and {{Emanation Body}}. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}, {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}, and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

An Emanation Body who performs the twelve principal deeds, such as Buddha Shakyamuni, is called a â€˜Supreme Emanation Bodyâ€™. From the point of view of external aspect, such an emanation is supreme, but from the point of view of nature, all beings emanated by a Buddha, however mundane in aspect, are supreme beings. Therefore, we should not infer from the name â€˜Supreme Emanation Bodyâ€™ that there are higher and lower emanations of Buddha. In essence, all Buddhaâ€™s emanations are fully enlightened beings. See also {{Buddhaâ€™s bodies}}. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}, {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}, and {{Ocean of Nectar}}..

entries.title: Sutra
definitions: The teachings of Buddha that are open to everyone to practise without the need for empowerment. These include Buddhaâ€™s teachings of the three turnings of the Wheel of Dharma.

entries.title: Svatantrika
definitions: See {{Madhyamika}}.

entries.title: Tangkha
definitions: A traditional Buddhist painting of a holy being.

entries.title: TÃ¤ngyur
definitions: The collection of commentaries to Buddhaâ€™s teachings that have been translated from Sanskrit into Tibetan. See also {{Kangyur}}.

entries.title: Tantra
definitions: Synonymous with Secret Mantra. Tantric teachings are distinguished from Sutra teachings in that they reveal methods for training the mind by bringing the future result, or Buddhahood, into the present path. Tantric practitioners overcome ordinary appearances and conceptions by visualizing their body, environment, enjoyments, and deeds as those of a Buddha. Tantra is the supreme path to full enlightenment. Tantric practices are to be done in private and only by those who have received a Tantric empowerment. See {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}} and {{Mahamudra Tantra}}.

entries.title: Tantric bodhichitta
definitions: A wish to attain enlightenment as a Tantric Deity in order to rescue sentient beings from samsara as quickly as possible. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}} and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}} .

entries.title: Tantric Mahamudra
definitions: See {{Mahamudra}}.

entries.title: Tara
definitions: A female Buddha who is a manifestation of the ultimate wisdom of all the Buddhas. â€˜Taraâ€™ means â€˜Rescuerâ€™. Since she is a wisdom Buddha, and since she is a manifestation of the completely purified wind element, Tara is able to help us very quickly.

entries.title: Tathagata
definitions: The Sanskrit for `A Being Gone Beyondâ€™, which is another term for Buddha.

entries.title: Ten directions
definitions: The four cardinal directions, the four intermediate directions, and the directions above and below.

entries.title: Tenets
definitions: There are four schools of Buddhist tenets, which are four philosophical views taught by Buddha according to the inclinations and dispositions of disciples. They are the Vaibashika, Sautrantika, Chittamatra, and Madhyamika schools. The first two are Hinayana schools and the second two are Mahayana schools. They are studied in sequence, the lower tenets being the means by which the higher ones are understood. See {{Meaningful to Behold}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Ten perfections
definitions: The six perfections as well as the perfections of skilful means, prayer, force, and exalted awareness. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Thing
definitions: A phenomenon that is produced and disintegrates within a moment. Synonymous with impermanent phenomenon, functioning thing, and product. (or, sometimes, just say â€œSee Functioning thing.â€)

entries.title: Thirty-five Confession Buddhas
definitions: Thirty-five Buddhas who have special powers to purify negativities and downfalls in those who recite their names with faith. See {{The Bodhisattva Vow}}.

entries.title: Thirty-seven realizations conducive to enlightenment
definitions: Any spiritual path that leads to enlightenment. There are seven groups: four close placements of mindfulness, four correct abandoners, four legs of miracle powers, five powers, five forces, seven branches of enlightenment, and eight branches of superior paths. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Thirty-two major signs
definitions: Sometimes called the `major marksâ€™. Special characteristics of a Buddhaâ€™s form. Examples are the sign of the wheel on the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. The eighty indications, sometimes called the `minor marksâ€™, include signs such as copper-coloured nails.

entries.title: Three higher trainings
definitions: Training in moral discipline, concentration, and wisdom motivated by renunciation or bodhichitta.

entries.title: Three Jewels
definitions: The three objects of refuge: Buddha Jewel, Dharma Jewel, and Sangha Jewel. They are called `Jewelsâ€™ because they are both rare and precious. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Three principal aspects of the path
definitions: The realizations of renunciation, bodhichitta, and wisdom realizing emptiness. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Three realms
definitions: The three levels within samsara: the desire realm, the form realm, and the formless realm. The desire realm is the environment of hell beings, hungry spirits, animals, human beings, demi-gods, and the gods who enjoy the five objects of desire. The form realm is the environment of the gods who possess form. The formless realm is the environment of the gods who do not possess form. Beings of the desire realm have powerful delusions, beings of the form realm have more subtle delusions, and beings of the formless realm have very subtle delusions. See also {{Desire realm}}, {{Form realm}}, and {{Formless realm}}.

entries.title: Three times
definitions: Past, present, and future. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Three worlds
definitions: The naga world beneath, the human world above, and the god world on high. See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Torma offering
definitions: A special food offering made according to either Sutric or Tantric rituals. See {{Essence of Vajrayana}}.

entries.title: Training the mind
definitions: â€˜Lojongâ€™ in Tibetan. A special lineage of instructions that came from Buddha Shakyamuni through Manjushri and Shantideva to Atisha and the Kadampa Geshes, which emphasizes the generation of bodhichitta through the practices of equalizing and exchanging self with others combined with taking and giving. See {{Universal Compassion}} and {{Eight Steps to Happiness}}.

entries.title: Training the Mind in Seven Points
definitions: A commentary to Eight Verses of Training the Mind, composed by Bodhisattva Chekhawa. For a full commentary, see {{Universal Compassion}}.

entries.title: Tranquil abiding
definitions: A concentration that possesses the special bliss of physical and mental suppleness that is attained in dependence upon completing the nine mental abidings. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Meaningful to Behold}}.

entries.title: Transference of consciousness
definitions: â€˜Powaâ€™ in Tibetan. A practice for transferring the consciousness to a Pure Land at the time of death. See {{Living Meaningfully, Dying Joyfully}} and {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Trijang Rinpoche (AD 1901-1981)
definitions: A special Tibetan Lama of the twentieth century who was an emanation of Buddha Shakyamuni, Heruka, Atisha, Amitabha, and Je Tsongkhapa. Also known as `Trijang Dorjechangâ€™ and `Losang Yesheâ€™.

entries.title: True cessation
definitions: The ultimate nature of a mind freed from any obstruction by means of a true path. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: True existence
definitions: Existence in any way independent of conceptual imputation.

entries.title: True-grasping
definitions: A conceptual mind that apprehends true existence.

entries.title: True origin
definitions: An action or a delusion that is the main cause of a true suffering. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: True path
definitions: A spiritual path held by a wisdom directly realizing emptiness. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: True suffering
definitions: A contaminated object produced by delusions and karma. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: Truth Body
definitions: â€˜Dharmakayaâ€™ in Sanskrit. The Wisdom Truth Body and the Nature Body of a Buddha. The first is Buddhaâ€™s omniscient mind, and the second is the emptiness, or ultimate nature, of his or her mind. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}, {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}, and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Tsog offering
definitions: An offering made by an assembly of Heroes and Heroines. See {{Essence of Vajrayana}}.

entries.title: Tsongkhapa
definitions: See {{Je Tsongkhapa}}.

entries.title: Tummo
definitions: Tibetan word for â€˜inner fireâ€™. An inner heat located at the centre of the navel channel wheel. See {{Clear Light of Bliss}}.

entries.title: Tushita
definitions: â€˜Joyful Landâ€™ in English, â€˜Gandenâ€™ in Tibetan. The Pure Land of Buddha Maitreya. Both Je Tsongkhapa and Atisha went to this Pure Land after they passed away. See {{Heart Jewel}}.

entries.title: Twelve dependent-related links
definitions: Dependent-related ignorance, compositional actions, consciousness, name and form, six sources, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, existence, birth, and ageing and death. These twelve links are causes and effects that keep ordinary beings bound within samsara. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: Twelve principal deeds
definitions: The principal deeds of a Supreme Emanation Body: (1) descent from Joyful Land, (2) conception in a motherâ€™s womb, (3) birth, (4) mastery of youthful skills and sports, (5) enjoyments with a wife and retinue, (6) ordination, (7) the practice of asceticism, (8) meditation under the Bodhi Tree, (9) overcoming the maras, (10) showing the attainment of enlightenment, (11) turning the Wheel of Dharma, (12) showing the manner of passing away. See {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: Twelve sources
definitions: The six powers (the eye sense power and so forth) and the six objects of those powers (visual forms and so forth). See {{Heart of Wisdom}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Twenty-four holy places
definitions: Twenty-four special places in this world where the mandalas of Heruka and Vajrayogini still remain. They are: Puliramalaya, Dzalandhara, Odiyana, Arbuta, Godawari, RameshÃ¶ri, Dewikoti, Malawa, Kamarupa, Ote, Trishakune, Kosala, Kalinga, Lampaka, Kancha, Himalaya, Pretapuri, Grihadewata, Shauraktra, Suwanadvipa, Nagara, Sindhura, Maru, and Kuluta. See {{Essence of Vajrayana}} and {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Two collections
definitions: The collections of merit and wisdom. See {{Collection of merit}} and {{#Collection of wisdom}}.

entries.title: Two extremes
definitions: Buddha explains the middle way by refuting the two extremes: the extreme of existence (that phenomena are inherently existent) and the extreme of non-existence (that phenomena do not exist at all). See {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Two truths
definitions: Conventional truth and ultimate truth. See {{Meaningful to Behold}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Two obstructions
definitions: Obstructions to liberation and obstructions to omniscience. Hinayana Foe Destroyers and Bodhisattvas above the seventh ground have abandoned the obstructions to liberation but not the obstructions to omniscience. Consequently, when they are not in meditative equipoise on emptiness, objects appear to them as inherently existent. See also Obstructions to liberation and Obstructions to omniscience.

entries.title: Ultimate bodhichitta
definitions: A wisdom motivated by conventional bodhichitta that directly realizes emptiness. See {{Universal Compassion}} and {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Ultimate nature
definitions: All phenomena have two natures â€“ a conventional nature and an ultimate nature. In the case of a table, for example, the table itself, and its shape, colour, and so forth are all the conventional nature of the table. The ultimate nature of the table is the tableâ€™s lack of inherent existence. The conventional nature of a phenomenon is a conventional truth, and its ultimate nature is an ultimate truth. See {{Heart of Wisdom}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Ultimate truth
definitions: The ultimate nature of all phenomena, emptiness. See {{Heart of Wisdom}}, {{Meaningful to Behold}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Uncommon Close Lineage
definitions: See {{Kadam Emanation Scripture}}.

entries.title: Uncommon Whispered Lineage
definitions: of the Virtuous Tradition See {{Kadam Emanation Scripture}}.

entries.title: Uncompounded space
definitions: Lack of obstructive contact. So called because it is not produced by causes and conditions and so is permanent. Also known as â€˜unproduced spaceâ€™. See {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: Uncontaminated bliss
definitions: A realization of bliss conjoined with a wisdom directly realizing emptiness. See Guide to Dakini Land, {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}, and {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Union of No More Learning
definitions: A union of the pure illusory body and meaning clear light that has abandoned the obstructions to omniscience. Synonymous with Buddhahood. See {{Clear Light of Bliss}}, {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}, and {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Union that needs learning
definitions: A union of the pure illusory body and meaning clear light that has not yet abandoned the obstructions to omniscience. See {{Clear Light of Bliss}}, {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}, and {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Unobservable compassion
definitions: See {{Great compassion}}.

entries.title: Unproduced space
definitions: Lack of obstructive contact. So called because it is not produced by causes and conditions and so is permanent. Also known as â€˜uncompounded spaceâ€™. See {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: Ushnisha
definitions: A Buddhaâ€™s crown protruberance. One of the thirty-two major signs.

entries.title: Vaibhashika
definitions: The lower of the two schools of Hinayana tenets. This school does not accept self-cognizers and asserts external objects to be truly existent. See {{Meaningful to Behold}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Vairochana
definitions: The manifestation of the aggregate of form of all Buddhas. He has a white-coloured body.

entries.title: Vajra
definitions: Generally, the Sanskrit word `vajraâ€™ means indestructible like a diamond and powerful like a thunderbolt. In the context of Secret Mantra, it can mean the indivisibility of method and wisdom, omniscient great wisdom, or spontaneous great bliss. It is also the name given to a metal ritual object. See {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Vajra and bell
definitions: A ritual sceptre symbolizing great bliss and a ritual hand-bell symbolizing emptiness. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}} and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Vajra body
definitions: Generally, the channels, drops, and inner winds. More specifically, the pure illusory body. The body of a Buddha is known as the `resultant vajra bodyâ€™. See {{Clear Light of Bliss}}.

entries.title: Vajra brothers/sisters
definitions: Practitioners who have received any Highest Yoga Tantra empowerment from the same Vajra Master, either at the same time or at different times. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}} and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Vajradaka Burning Offering
definitions: A special purification practice in which our negativities and downfalls are transformed into black sesame seeds, which are offered to Vajradaka who appears from a blazing fire to consume them. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}} and {{Living Meaningfully, Dying Joyfully}}.

entries.title: Vajradhara
definitions: The founder of Vajrayana, or Tantra. He appears directly only to highly realized Bodhisattvas to whom he gives Tantric teachings. To benefit other living beings with less merit, he manifested in the more visible form of Buddha Shakyamuni. He also said that in degenerate times he would appear in an ordinary form as a Spiritual Guide. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Vajra-like concentration
definitions: The last moment of the Mahayana path of meditation. It is the antidote to the very subtle obstructions to omniscience. In the next moment, one attains the Mahayana Path of No More Learning, or Buddhahood.

entries.title: Vajra Master
definitions: A fully qualified Tantric Spiritual Guide. See {{Great Treasury of Merit}}.

entries.title: Vajrapani
definitions: The embodiment of the power of all the Buddhas. He appears in a wrathful aspect, displaying his power to overcome outer, inner, and secret obstacles. At the time of Buddha Shakyamuni he manifested as a Bodhisattva disciple in order to show Buddhaâ€™s disciples how to be perfect Mahayana disciples.

entries.title: Vajra posture
definitions: The perfect cross-legged posture. See also Seven-point posture of Vairochana. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Vajra recitation
definitions: A mantra recitation produced from inner winds that is practised in conjunction with Vajrayana practices. See {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Vajrasattva
definitions: Buddha Vajrasattva is the aggregate of consciousness of all the Buddhas, appearing in the aspect of a white-coloured Deity specifically in order to purify sentient beingsâ€™ negativity. He is the same nature as Buddha Vajradhara, differing only in aspect. The practice of meditation and recitation of Vajrasattva is a very powerful method for purifying our impure mind and actions. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}}:.

entries.title: Vajrayana
definitions: The Secret Mantra vehicle. See also {{Secret Mantra}}. See {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Vajrayana Mahamudra
definitions: See {{Mahamudra}}.

entries.title: Vajrayogini
definitions: A female Highest Yoga Tantra Deity who is the embodiment of indivisible bliss and emptiness. She is the same nature as Heruka. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Valid cognizer/mind
definitions: A cognizer that is non-deceptive with respect to its engaged object. There are two types: inferential valid cognizers and direct valid cognizers. See {{Heart of Wisdom}} and {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Valid mind
definitions: See {{Valid cognizer}}.

entries.title: Vast path
definitions: The vast path includes all the method practices from the initial cultivation of compassion through to the final attainment of the Form Body of a Buddha. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Ocean of Nectar}}.

entries.title: Vasubhandu
definitions: A great Indian Buddhist scholar of the fifth century who was converted to the Mahayana by his older brother, Asanga. He wrote Treasury of Abhidharma (Skt. Abhidharmakosha).

entries.title: Vehicle/Spiritual vehicle
definitions: An exalted awareness that leads to oneâ€™s final spiritual destination. See also Path/Spiritual path, Hinayana, Mahayana, and Vajrayana. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}} and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: View of the transitory collection
definitions: A type of self-grasping of persons that grasps oneâ€™s own I as being an inherently existent I. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}, {{Ocean of Nectar}}, and {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Vinaya Sutras
definitions: Sutras in which Buddha principally explains the practice of moral discipline, and in particular the Pratimoksha moral discipline.

entries.title: Virtue
definitions: A phenomenon that functions as a main cause of happiness. It can refer to virtuous minds, virtuous actions, virtuous imprints, or the ultimate virtue of nirvana. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Virtuous Tradition
definitions: See {{Gelugpa}}.

entries.title: Visual form
definitions: The object of eye awareness. See {{Heart of Wisdom}}.

entries.title: Vow
definitions: A virtuous determination to abandon particular faults that is generated in conjunction with a traditional ritual. The three sets of vows are the Pratimoksha vows of individual liberation, the Bodhisattva vows, and the Secret Mantra or Tantric vows. See {{The Bodhisattva Vow}} and {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}.

entries.title: Wheel of Dharma
definitions: Buddha gave his teachings in three main phases, which are known as â€˜the three turnings of the Wheel of Dharmaâ€™. During the first Wheel he taught the four noble truths, during the second he taught the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras and revealed the Madhyamika-Prasangika view, and during the third he taught the Chittamatra view. These teachings were given according to the inclinations and dispositions of his disciples. Buddhaâ€™s final view is that of the second Wheel. Dharma is compared to the precious wheel, one of the possessions of a legendary chakravatin king. This wheel could transport the king across great distances in a very short time, and it is said that wherever the precious wheel travelled the king reigned. In a similar way, when Buddha revealed the path to enlightenment he was said to have â€˜turned the Wheel of Dharmaâ€™ because, wherever these teachings are present, deluded minds are brought under control.

entries.title: Wheel of Life
definitions: A diagram depicting the twelve dependent-related links and the four noble truths. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Winds
definitions: See {{Inner winds}}.

entries.title: Wisdom
definitions: A virtuous, intelligent mind that makes its primary mind realize its object thoroughly. A wisdom is a spiritual path that functions to release our mind from delusions or their imprints. An example of wisdom is the correct view of emptiness. See {{Heart of Wisdom}} and {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Wisdom being
definitions: An actual Buddha, especially one who is invited to unite with a visualized commitment being.

entries.title: Wisdom Truth Body
definitions: Buddhaâ€™s omniscient mind. See also {{Truth Body}}. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}, {{Tantric Grounds and Paths}}, and

entries.title: Wishfulfilling jewel
definitions: A legendary jewel that, like Aladdinâ€™s lamp, grants whatever is wished for.

entries.title: Wrong awareness
definitions: A cognizer that is mistaken with respect to its engaged, or apprehended, object. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Wrong view
definitions: An intellectually-formed wrong awareness that denies the existence of an object that it is necessary to understand to attain liberation or enlightenment â€“ for example, denying the existence of enlightened beings, karma, or rebirth. See {{Joyful Path of Good Fortune}}.

entries.title: Yama
definitions: See {{Lord of Death}}.

entries.title: Yamantaka
definitions: A Highest Yoga Tantra Deity who is a wrathful manifestation of Manjushri.

entries.title: Yidam
definitions: See {{Deity}}.

entries.title: Yoga
definitions: A term used for various spiritual practices that entail maintaining a special view, such as Guru yoga and the yogas of sleeping, rising, and experiencing nectar. â€˜Yogaâ€™ also refers to â€˜unionâ€™, such as the union of tranquil abiding and superior seeing. See {{Guide to Dakini Land}}.

entries.title: Yoga Tantra
definitions: See {{Four classes of Tantra}}.

entries.title: Yogic direct perceiver
definitions: A direct perceiver that realizes a subtle object directly, in dependence upon its uncommon dominant condition, a concentration that is a union of tranquil abiding and superior seeing. See {{Understanding the Mind}}.

entries.title: Yogi/Yogini
definitions: Sanskrit words usually referring to a male or a female meditator who has attained the union of tranquil abiding and superior seeing.
